{{Infobox person | name = Jaime del Burgo Torres | image = ULL.98.12.3.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jaime Percal Torres | birth_date = 1912 | birth_place = [[Pamplona]], Spain | death_date = 2005 | death_place = Pamplona, Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = Spanish | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = public servant | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Comunión Tradicionalista]], [[FET]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Jaime del Burgo Torres''' (1912 – 2005) was a Spanish official, writer and a [[Carlist]] activist. He is noted mostly as a historian; his works focus on [[Navarre]] and the [[Carlist Wars|Carlist wars]]. As a public servant he is known as longtime head of Navarrese library network, regional Ministry of Information delegate and a governmental and self-governmental tourist official. As a Carlist he is acknowledged as moving spirit behind the Navarrese [[Requeté]] in the 1930s and as representative of the [[Carloctavismo|Carloctavista]] faction during early [[Francoism]]. He also wrote novels, poems and dramas.
==Family and youth== [[File:Pamplona model.JPG|thumbnail|left|[[Pamplona]], early 20th century]] There is next to nothing known about del Burgo’s paternal ancestors. Though some authors claim that already his grandfather contributed to the Carlist cause,<ref>''Fallece a los 92 años Jaime del Burgo Torres, historiador, periodista y escritor'', [in:] ''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref> no other account confirms this or clarifies his identity; the official del Burgo’s birth certificate refers to his paternal grandparents as "abuelos incognitos".<ref>see [http://postimg.org/image/qbbrnqqoh/ here ]</ref> None of the sources consulted offers much information on his father Eusebio (1887-1970).<ref>see ''Eusebio del Burgo Pascual'' entry at ''Geni'' genealogical service available [http://www.geni.com/people/Eusebio-del-Burgo-Pascual/6000000019298109173 here]</ref> Even his exact surname remains unclear; some sources claim he was named [[Eusebio del Burgo Pascual]]<ref>see ''Eusebio del Burgo Pascual'' entry at ''Geni'' genealogical service available [http://www.geni.com/people/Eusebio-del-Burgo-Pascual/6000000019298109173 here]</ref> while an official document certifies he was born Eusebio Percal and it only changed to Eusebio del Burgo Pascual in 1926.<ref>see Jaime del Burgo's certificate of birth, available [http://postimg.org/image/qbbrnqqoh/ here]</ref> According to one author he originated from the Navarrese town of [[Villava – Atarrabia|Villava]],<ref>''Burgo Tajadura, Jaime Ignacio'', [in:] ''[[Diccionario Biografíco Español]]'', vol. 9, Madrid 2010, {{ISBN|9788496849655}}, p. 668, available [http://fabregaspere.com/blog2/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/2010.00.00.a.Esteve-Bures-i-Arderiu.RAH_.pdf here]</ref> according to another he was born in Pamplona.<ref>see [http://postimg.org/image/qbbrnqqoh/ here]) his father was born in Pamplona</ref> Nothing is known about his profession; politically he sympathised with the Carlists and at the age of 45 took part in street brawls.<ref>Fernando Mikelarena, ''Cuando los carlistas cantaban en San Fermín "no estamos todos, faltan los presos"'', [in:] ''El blog de Fernando Mikelarena'', available [http://elblogdefernandomikelarena.blogspot.com/2013/07/cuando-los-carlistas-cantaban-en-san.html here]</ref> He married a [[Pamplona|pamplonesa]], Paula Torres Jacoiste (1887-1973).<ref>''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry at ''Geni'' service available [http://www.geni.com/people/Jaime-del-Burgo-Torres/6000000019295521515 here]</ref> Living in Pamplona, the couple had three sons and four daughters,<ref>''Paula Torres Jacoisti'' entry at ''Geni'' service available [http://www.geni.com/people/Paula-Torres-Jacoisti/6000000019297600947 here]</ref> all brought up in [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] ambience<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05, José Fermín Garralda Arizcun, ''Sin caer en el olvido. Jaime del Burgo Torres (1912-2005). Historiador polifacético en su tercer aniversario'', [in:] ''Arbil'' 118 (2008), available [http://www.arbil.org/118garr.htm here]</ref> and fervently Catholic atmosphere, at times bordering exaltation.<ref>there were seer sessions run by Catholic visionaries in the del Burgo family house in Pamplona, see William A. Christian, ''Visionaries: The Spanish Republic and the Reign of Christ'', Berkeley 1996, {{ISBN|0520200403}}, 9780520200401, p. 191</ref> [[File:Palacio Nacional de Vinicultura-Atarrabia.JPG|thumb|[[Villava]], Escuela de Peritos Agrícolas]] Jaime Victoriano Martin was born as Percal y Torres<ref>[http://postimg.org/image/qbbrnqqoh/ here]</ref> and it is not clear in what circumstances the family changed their surname to del Burgo. Nothing is known about his early childhood; as a teenager he trained to become "[[:es:Peritaje mercantil|perito mercantil]]"<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008; ''ABC'' 25.10.05 claims he was "profesor mercantil", see [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2005/10/25/044.html here]</ref> at unidentified school, possibly in [[Villava]].<ref>at that time the only local institution enabling this sort of career was Escuela de Peritos Agrícolas in Villava</ref> He has never pursued a professional commercial career; during his adolescence years he was increasingly engaged in public activities, consuming more and more of his time. Del Burgo married Maria de las Mercedes Tajadura Goñi (1911-1999);<ref>see ''María de las Mercedes Tajadura Goñi'' at ''Geni'' service available [http://www.geni.com/people/Mar%C3%ADa-de-las-Mercedes-Tajadura-Go%C3%B1i/6000000019295569440 here], also ''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05; Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> her father, Federico Tajadura Arnaíz, was a military official.<ref>''Diario Oficial del Ministerio de la Guerra'', 30.06.19, available [http://bibliotecavirtualdefensa.es/BVMDefensa/i18n/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=11257 here], also ''BOE'' 24.10.53, abailable [http://www.boe.es/datos/pdfs/BOE//1953/297/A06316-06316.pdf here]</ref> The couple had three children, Mercedes, Jaime Ignacio and Maria Antonia.<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref> Upon his death he left three children, thirteen grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> His son [[Jaime Ignacio del Burgo Tajadura]]<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref> was a conservative politician and the Prime Minister of Navarre (president of [[:es:Diputación Foral de Navarra|Diputacion Foral de Navarra]]) in 1979-1984.<ref>''Burgo Tajadura, Jaime Ignacio'', [in:] ''[[Diccionario Biografíco Español]]'', pp. 668-669</ref> His grandson [[Ignacio del Burgo Azpíroz]], otherwise a Pamplona lawyer, gained wider recognition as author of a historical novel.<ref>Carlos Mata-Indurain, ''Panorama de la novela histórica en Navarra'', [in:] M. Casado Velarde, C. Saralegui Platero (eds.), ''Pulchre, bene, recte: estudios en homenaje al prof. Fernando González Ollé'', Pamplona 2002, {{ISBN|8431319445}}, p. 935, see ''Ignacio del Burgo Azpiroz'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/50164 here]</ref> Another of his grandchildren, an entrepreneur [[Jaime del Burgo Azpíroz]],<ref>see his own site available [http://jaimedelburgo.com/ here]</ref> married an older sister of [[Letizia Ortiz]], becoming brother-in-law of [[Felipe VI of Spain]]<ref>M. Romero, ''Jaime del Burgo el conquistador'', [in:] ''La Razón'' 03.05.12, available [http://www.larazon.es/detalle_hemeroteca/noticias/LA_RAZON_453432/4119-jaime-del-burgo-el-conquistador here]</ref><ref>{{es}} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0L6f8j3P2TE Crónica Rosa: Telma Ortiz y Jaime del Burgo, juntos de nuevo - 21/05/14]</ref>.
==Rebel== [[File:San Fermin Portada de Programa.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[virility]] Pamplona-style]] Already as a youngster del Burgo engaged in the Carlist juvenile organization, [[Juventud Jaimista]], in 1930 becoming secretary of the Navarrese branch of the organization;<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref> a year later he set up a local Carlist weekly ''La Esperanza'', trying his hand as an editor, manager and contributor.<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> In 1931 he was among those founding provincial branch<ref>Manuel Ferrer Muñoz, ''Carlismo y violencia en la II República 1931-36: la organización del Requeté vasco-navarro'', [in:] ''Sociedad Benéfica de Historiadores Aficionados y Creadores'' website available [http://www.sbhac.net/Republica/Introduccion/Conspira/Carlistas.htm here]</ref> of the newly born national Carlist student association, [[Agrupación Escolar Tradicionalista]].<ref>founded in 1930 as a belligerent competitor to Confederación de Estudiantes Católicos Españoles, Eduardo González Calleja, ''Rebelión en las aulas: un siglo de movilizaciones estudiantiles en España (1865-1968)'', [in:] ''Ayer'' 59 (2005), p. 37</ref> Remaining at its helm until the outbreak of the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]],<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> del Burgo exercised enormous influence on the group and beyond, especially as in 1934 it launched its press tribune, the ''a.e.t.'' weekly.<ref>Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, p. 134</ref>
Initially Navarrese AET focused on juvenile activities like sport, leisure and outdoor, though they were increasingly flavored by cult of brotherhood, Carlist heroes, activism and virility,<ref>embodied e.g. in long, exhaustive night marches around Pamplona, Javier Ugarte Tellería, ''La nueva Covadonga insurgente: orígenes sociales y culturales de la sublevación de 1936 en Navarra y el País Vasco'', Madrid 1998, {{ISBN|847030531X}}, 9788470305313, pp. 280-281</ref> combined with anti-materialist spiritualism and a drive for change.<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, pp. 276-290</ref> A present scholar relates them to [[Georges Sorel|Sorel]], [[Filippo Tommaso Marinetti|Marinetti]], [[T.S. Eliot]] and [[W. B. Yeats]],<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, pp. 280-1</ref> also drawing parallels between aetistas and a [[Millenarism|millenarist]] Romanian ultra-Right [[Legion of Archangel Michael]];<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 289</ref> another one points to fascist influence<ref>Eduardo González Calleja, ''La violencia y sus discursos. Los límites de la "fascistización" de la derecha española durante el régimen de la II República'', [in:] ''Ayer'' 71 (2008), pp. 85-116, esp sub-chapter ''"Cruzados de la causa": la reactualización de la cultura insurreccional carlista'', pp. 94-102</ref> Indeed, the Sorelian thread manifested itself by social radicalism of Del Burgo and ''a.e.t.'' The group departed from orthodox Traditionalist line, commiserating with masses of miserable beings pitted against the politically dominant potentates; they advocated limitation of wealth and regularization of profits. Contemptuous towards Carlist landowners like [[José María Lamamié de Clairac|José Lamamié]] and [[Jaime Chicharro Sánchez-Guió|Jaime Chicharro]], the students supported Agrarian Reform, obstructed by feudal egoism of the odious grandees of grain.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 172</ref> The group called for a Carlist Revolution<ref>some scholars see 2 trends: carlismo nacional and revolución carlista, Juan Carlos Peñas Bernaldo de Quirós, ''El Carlismo, la República y la Guerra Civil (1936-1937). De la conspiración a la unificación'', Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|8487863523}}, 9788487863523, p. 21; some authors reduce del Burgo’s revolution to socia issues, see Julio Aróstegui, Eduardo Calleja, ''La tradición recuperada: El requeté carlista y la insurrección'', [in:] ''Historia Contemporanea'' 11 (1994), p. 38. He declared: "Somos revolucionarios. Lo oyen ustedes? Revolucionarios!", quoted after Eduardo Gonzales Calleja, ''Contrarrevolucionarios'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|9788420664552}}, p. 190</ref> aiming at a good clean-up of society,<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 287</ref> and was greeted with amazement by the older Carlist generation. [[File:A.e.t..JPG|thumbnail|''a.e.t''.]] The rupturista stance of the aetistas had nothing in common with social radicalism of the [[Second Spanish Republic|republican]] Left.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 174; a somewhat opposite view in Steven Henry Martin, ''The Commonality of Enemies: Carlism and anarchism in modern Spain, 1868-1937'' [MA thesis], Peterborough 2014, p. 120: "young Carlists in the age of mass politics of the early 20th century, like those in the Agrupación de Estudiantes Tradicionalistas (AET), were incorporating ideas about egalitarianism, autonomy and wealth redistribution that linked the old values of Carlism to the new ones of anarchism"</ref> It remained extremely hostile towards the mass workers’ parties, their militancy to be confronted with vengeance and repaid with "bomb, dagger and fire",<ref>"seamos hombres y sepamos vengar al caído; aunque sea haciendo poner para todo el año a los socialistas crespones de luto en sus centros: Porque contra esos cualquier procedimiento que se utilice es bueno: la bomba, el puñal y el incendio", quoted after José María Esparza Zabalegi, ''Agur, Del Burgo'', [in:] ''Diario de Noticias de Navarra'', see [http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/foro/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=18123&start=30 noticias de navarra forum]</ref> the cult of activism bordering the cult of violence. Strategy of Carlist leaders was denounced as ineffective; in 1934 del Burgo and the young, having declared themselves rebels fed up with legality, accused the old junteros of 3 years of inactivity,<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, pp. 284-287</ref> their only achievement having been the alliance with caciques and debris of the fallen liberal monarchy. AET despised parliamentary activities of the party elders<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 281</ref> and especially accommodation with the [[Alfonsist monarchist|Alfonsists]].<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 135</ref> The intemperate tone of the aetistas shocked the Navarrese Carlist authorities and made them call for moderation.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, pp. 134-5; Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 279 claims that Joaquín Baleztena consented to the ''a.e.t.'' tone</ref> As a result, Del Burgo did not regret [[Tomás Domínguez Arévalo]] resignation and welcomed the appointment of [[Manuel Fal Conde]].<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 140</ref>
==Requeté== In 1931 del Burgo engaged in the Carlist militia [[Requeté]], at that time undergoing rapid expansion and partial restructuring.<ref>Aróstegui, Calleja 1994, p. 36</ref> He demonstrated enormous dedication and great organizational capacity,<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 269</ref> along [[Generoso Huarte]]<ref>Huarte was conservative and somaten-style, while Burgo was radical and callejero-style, Ugarte Tellería 1998, pp. 267, 277</ref> becoming one of key field commanders and focusing on the province of Pamplona.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 63</ref> Participating in street brawls against [[PSOE|socialist]] groups,<ref>José María Esparza Zabalegi, ''Agur, Del Burgo'', [in:] ''Diario de Noticias de Navarra'', quoted after [http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/opinion/foros/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=18123&start=30 noticias de navarra forum]</ref> he was arrested following the clashes of April 1932.<ref>denounced in the press as "matón terrorista e incendiario"; some scholars charge him with provoking riots with cost 2 lives, see Iñaki Egaña, ''Los crímenes de Franco en Euskal Herria, 1936-1940'', Tafalla 2009, {{ISBN|8481365599}}, 9788481365597, pp. 23-24</ref> Charged with trafficking arms – which he did indeed – del Burgo was acquitted due to lack of evidence, though in total he remained behind bars for 6 months.<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 78</ref> Released, he again became one of the most active Requeté operatives in Navarre,<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 145</ref> especially under the new, strictly military organization engineered by [[José Enrique Varela|Varela]].<ref>Manuel Ferrer Muñoz, ''Carlismo y violencia en la II República 1931-36: la organización del Requeté vasco-navarro'', [in:] ''Sociedad Benéfica de Historiadores Aficionados y Creadores'' website</ref>
Early 1934 del Burgo led one of the two already formed Pamplona piquetes.<ref>according to the Requeté structure as designed by Varela, a tercio (battalion) consisted of 3 requetés (250 men each); a requeté in turn consisted of 3 piquetes (70 men each), see Antonio Lizarza, ''Memorias de la conspiración'', [in:] ''Navarra fue la primera'', Pamplona 2006, {{ISBN|8493508187}}, p. 41</ref> During the spring he and 14 other Carlists travelled to [[Fascist Italy (1922–43)|Italy]] under the false [[Peru]]vian identities; at the [[:it:Poligono di Furbara|Furbara]] air base they underwent specialist military training, focusing on usage of [[machine gun]]s and [[grenades]], [[infantry]] tactics and urban warfare.<ref>Gonzales Calleja 2011, p. 198</ref> Back in Spain, del Burgo wrote tactical rulebook with instructions as to group alignment and positioning, fire drills, march and engagement distances etc., all calibrated for small groups and mostly urban combat.<ref>Gonzales Calleja 2011, p. 199</ref> Promoted to [[lieutenant]], he broadened his training to the Carlist [[Non commissioned officer|NCOs]].<ref>3 times a week each session 8-10 hrs, Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 270, Gonzales Calleja 2011, p. 263, Aróstegui, Calleja 1994, p. 46</ref> Early 1936 Pamplona could already present one [[battalion]]; del Burgo was leading one of its 3 [[Company|companies]].<ref>dubbed "batallón sagrado" for its symbolical and prestigious standing, Ugarte Tellería 1998, pp. 262-3</ref>
Shortly before and during the first day of the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|coup]] del Burgo was instrumental to organizing the Pamplona Requeté units.<ref>Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 263, Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 174, Gonzales Calleja 2011, p. 386</ref> The Pamplona tercio was fragmented, del Burgo’s company incorporated into a mixed 7th Batallón del Regimiento de América.<ref>a mixed unit composed of one company of soldiers, one company of falangists and two companies of requetés, Julio Aróstegui, ''Combatientes Requetés en la Guerra Civil española, 1936-1939'', Madrid 2013, {{ISBN|9788499709758}}, p. 351-2</ref> He left Pamplona on July 19; following few days in [[La Rioja (Spain)|Rioja]], the battalion was moved to [[Navafria]] area in [[Sierra de Guadarrama]], in August engaged in heavy fighting for the [[Somosierra pass]].<ref>Aróstegui 2013, pp. 354-359; after the war the unit was referred to as Tercio del Rey, Aróstegui 2013, p. 352, Lizarza 2006, pp. 70-71</ref> In September he was withdrawn to a hospital in the rear.<ref>he suffered appendicitis according to Aróstegui 2013, p. 359; a fellow requeté who carried del Burgo on the stretcher claims he was wounded, see Pablo Larraz Andía, Víctor Sierra-Sesumaga (eds.), ''Requetés. De las trincheras al olvidio'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|9788499700465}}, p. 829</ref> Recovered, del Burgo co-organized the [[Álava|Álavese]]<ref>the ''Requeté.es'' site available [http://www.requetes.com/begonya.html here] claims the tercio was not Alavese but Biscay</ref> battalion of Tercio de Nuestra Señora de Begoña<ref>Diario de Navarra 25.10.05, ''Requeté'' site available [http://www.requetes.com/begonya.html here]</ref> and as its officer re-entered combat in [[Biscay]]. Reportedly shocked by destruction of [[Guernica]],<ref>Alberto Reig Tapia, ''Violencia y terror'', Madrid 1990, {{ISBN|9788476006931}}, p. 147</ref> he engaged in a related brawl against an army officer<ref>Iñaki Anasagasti, ''Cuando del Burgo defendía Guernica'', [in:] ''ianasagasti'' blog available [http://ianasagasti.blogs.com/mi_blog/2012/03/cuando-del-burgo-defend%C3%ADa-gernika.html here], Gonzales Calleja 2011, p. 863</ref> and deployed a requeté [[platoon]] safeguarding the [[Gernikako Arbola|symbolic oak]].<ref>according to his own version, shared by some historians, in order to prevent cutting down of the oak, allegedly planned by the Falangists; according to another version, it was a mere propaganda exercise intended as a damage limitation strategy, countering the efficient communist propaganda exploiting the Guernica bombing, compare Parido Carlista site [https://web.archive.org/web/20060902172409/http://www.eka-partidocarlista.com/delburgo.htm here], Herbert Rutledge Southworth, ''Guernica Guernica'', Berkeley 1977, {{ISBN|0520028309}}, 9780520028302, pp. 282-283, 299, 319, 322, 364, 379, 388, 463, 478, 482, Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, pp. 127-8</ref> In mid-June 1937 captain del Burgo was heavily wounded when storming the [[Bilbao]] [[Bilbao's Iron Ring|Iron Ring]].<ref>his own account available [http://www.requetes.com/begonya.html here]</ref> Evacuated, he has never returned to the frontline, serving as Delegado de Requetés del Seńorío de Vizcaya.<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref>
==Between ''falcondismo'' and ''carloctavismo''== [[File:Ideario by Jaime del Burgo.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|''Ideario'' by del Burgo]] During the [[:es:Decreto de Unificación|unification crisis]] of early 1937 del Burgo sided with the intransigent [[Manuel Fal Condé|falcondistas]],<ref>paradoxically, del Burgo unintentionally contributed to Fal’s exile. In August 1936, he suggested to Zamanillo that a Real Academia de Estudios Militares de la Comunión Tradicionalista is created, Jaime del Burgo Torres, ''Un episodio poco conocido de la guerra civil española. La Real Academia Militar de Requetés y el destierro de Fal Conde'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 196 (1992), pp. 485-487, also Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 232</ref> considering amalgamation into [[Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las JONS|FET]] a manipulation on part of the Navarrese.<ref>Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 276. Sending del Burgo to the front deprved Fal of an ally and facilitated Navarre falling to the rodeznistas, Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 218, Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 293 pursues a somewhat competitive interpretation, namely that del Burgo’s departure to the front was intended as disposing of a dangerous radical, comparable to marginalization of the Rohm SA faction within Nazism</ref> He labeled occasional enthusiasm for unification a "collective psychosis".<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 290; Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 59</ref> To underline Traditionalist identity, he was commissioned to compile a concise doctrinal handbook, published in April 1937 as ''Ideario Tradicionalista''.<ref>commissioned by Junta Carlista de Guerra de Vizcaya according to Garralda Arizcun 2008; the actual text available [http://carlismo.net/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Ideario-CTC-1979.pdf here]</ref> Some scholars claim that the collaborationists intended to get rid of del Burgo, still active in national AET,<ref>in April of 1937 del Burgo engaged in AET congress, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 32</ref> and send him abroad, as a Traditionalist tutor of [[Juan de Borbon|Don Juan]].<ref>Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 245, Iker Cantabrana Morras, ''Lo viejo y lo nuevo: Díputación-FET de las JONS. La convulsa dinámica política de la "leal" Alava (Primera parte: 1936-1938)'', [in:] ''Sancho el Sabio'' 21 (2004), {{ISSN|1131-5350}}, p. 167</ref> Late 1937 Fal considered del Burgo a man of trust<ref>Aurora Villanueva Martínez, ''Organizacion, actividad y bases del carlismo navarro durante el primer franquismo'' [in:] ''Geronimo de Uztariz'' 19 (2003), pp. 103, 115</ref> and included him on the list of potential replacements for the disloyal members of Navarrese junta, sent to the provincial leader [[Joaquín Baleztena Ascárate|Baleztena]].<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 152</ref> As the latter preferred to steer cautiously between [[:es:Tomás Domínguez Arévalo|rodeznistas]] and falcondistas and ignored the suggestion, it was only in 1939 that del Burgo entered the executive of [[Hermandad de los Caballeros Voluntarios de la Cruz]], intended as semi-official Fal’s outpost in Navarre.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, pp. 190-1</ref> In 1940 Fal appointed him to represent Navarre in a vasco-navarrese junta,<ref>which has never materialised; Arrúe was supposed to be representative of Guipúzcoa, Gaviria of Vizcaya, Lascuráin of Alava and del Burgo of Navarra, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 194</ref> though de Burgo’s opposition to unification was already burning out and giving way to sense of defeat, resignation and frustration.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, pp. 167-8</ref> Del Burgo’s departure from the falcondista camp stemmed not from differences on policy towards [[Francoism]], but was the result of dynastical disputes. Though in the mid-1930s he was fanatically loyal to the dynasty,<ref>Gonzales Calleja 2011, p. 191</ref> following the death of [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Don Alfonso Carlos]] del Burgo only hesitantly accepted the [[regency]] of [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]];<ref>according to del Burgo, "la Regencia es la muerte de cualquier monarquía", César Alcalá, ''Valoración historica del carlismo: pasado y futuro'', [in:] ''Arbil'' 79, available [http://www.arbil.org/%2879%29alca.htm here]</ref> instead, he advanced the cause of [[Archduke Karl Pius of Austria, Prince of Tuscany|Don Carlo Pio]] as early as on the frontline in 1937.<ref>which, apparently, was quite popular in Tercio de Begoña, see [http://www.requetes.com/begonya.html here]; before the Civil War the group named cruzadistas have advanced the cause of Don Carlos Pio; their paper ''La Fe'' concluded on 19.7.36 that if Don Javier is to become a regent, the only option is to declare Don Carlos Pio the king, César Alcalá, ''Cruzadistas y carloctavistas: historia de una conspiración'', Barcelona 2012, {{ISBN|9788493884253}}, pp. 192-194. Though he did remain technically loyal to the regent, in 1940 del Burgo again publicly called for declaring Carlos Pio the Carlist king, Francisco de las Heras y Borrero, ''Un pretendiente desconocido. Carlos de Habsburgo. El otro candidato de Franco'', Madrid 2004, {{ISBN|8497725565}}, p. 52</ref> When the latter officially raised his claim as Carlos VIII in 1943, del Burgo joined his followers - dubbed carloctavistas - and constructed a supporting dynastical interpretation.<ref>his theory was that Carlos V established a new dynasty; according to this version Don Javier, as not his descendant, represented another, non-Carlist dynasty, Jeremy MacClancy, ''The Decline of Carlism'', Reno 2000, {{ISBN|9780874173444}}, p. 290</ref> Unlike many Carlos VIII supporters he did not sympathize with the [[Axis powers|Axis]]<ref>Del Burgo blamed the [[Nazis]] for falangisation of Spain. His stance was also due to friendship with Jaime Lasuén, a French citizen and ex-combatant of Tercio de Begoña, who engaged in anti-Nazi French resistance. He sought refuge in Spain and was helped by del Burgo when on transit in Pamplona. He was later captured by the Francoist security in Madrid and given over to Gestapo; he died due to the tortures suffered. He handed del Burgo an envelope, to be collected by someone later on. Since no-one came to pick it up, del Burgo opened it years later and found that it contained an organigram of Nazi espionage network in the North of Spain; Martorell Pérez 2009, pp. 273-4; see also [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kJoNLMBdNRQ here], and for an alternative view, see [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TCN56ZUSD0 here]</ref> and did not enter the first carloctavista executive of 1943.<ref>the provinvial carloctavista jefe in Navarra was initially Emilio Dean Berro, see Alcalá 2012, pp. 249-50, to be later replaced by Antonio Lizarza, Alcalá 2012, pp. 273-4, 311</ref> It was only in 1945 that del Burgo became one of the [[Comunión Católico-Monárquica (carloctavista party)|Comunión Católico-Monárquica]] leaders<ref>theoretically supporting prospective Carlist candidates did not breach the loyalty to Don Javier as a regent; according to some scholars del Burgo was clearly disloyal, see Mercedes Vázquez de Prada Tiffe, ''La reorganización del carlismo vasco en los sesenta: entre la pasividad y el "separatismo"'', [in:] ''Vasconia. Cuadernos de Historia-Geografía'', 38 (2012), p. 107</ref> and vice-president of the claimant’s Navarrese Royal Council.<ref>Real Consejo del Reino de Navarra was presided by Emilio Dean Barro, Alcalá 2012, p. 276</ref> Don Carlos Pio was only 3 years del Burgo’s senior and equally radical; the two have forged a close relationship and exchanged a lengthy correspondence over the years.<ref>from 1944 to 1953, see [http://dadun.unav.edu/bitstream/10171/34177/1/167%20INVENTARIO.pdf here], samples re-printed in Heras y Borrero 2004, pp. 209-225</ref> In the late 1940s Del Burgo’s worked to capture new supporters<ref>like Antonio Lizarza, Antonio Pagoaga, Antonio Cabañas, Francisco Ciganda, Alcalá 2012, pp. 298-304; in 1946 he was in daily touch with [[Jesús Cora y Lira|Cora y Lira]], Alcalá 2012, p. 303, see also Heras y Borrero 2004, p. 72</ref> and in 1950 he managed to reconstruct Navarrese AET as a carloctavista organization.<ref>Alcalá 2012, p. 319</ref> However, at that time he was replaced as a key claimant's man in the province by [[:es:Antonio Lizarza|Antonio Lizarza]].<ref>Alcalá 2012, p. 306</ref>
The unexpected 1953 death of Don Carlos Pio left the carloctavistas puzzled. While most of the group focused on Carlos VIII's older brother [[Archduke Anton of Austria|Don Antonio]] and minor factions backed either his sons or another brother [[Archduke Franz Josef of Austria, Prince of Tuscany|Francisco Jose]], del Burgo advocated allegiance to the oldest daughter of Carlos VIII, Alejandra. According to del Burgo, having been a minor she would appear as "abanderada provisional", until the claim is passed to her anticipated male descendant.<ref>Heras y Borrero 2004, pp. 143-144</ref> This option received scarce support and no faction was built around it.<ref>Heras y Borrero 2004, pp. 140-166. Alejandra married in 1960, graduated in 1980 with work on Barcelona urban issues, see [http://www.raco.cat/index.php/RevistaGeografia/article/viewFile/46059/56864 here] and worked in the Barcelona city council. She became a socialist and lost any interest in the Carlist cause, ignored also by her two sons and a daughter, Heras y Borrero 2004, p. 152</ref> Del Burgo was left without clear dynastical allegiances; over time he developed a critical view of Carlos VIII, considering him "sold out" to Falange.<ref>quoted after Josep Carles Clemente, ''Raros, heterodoxos, disidentes y viñetas del Carlismo'', Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|842450707X}}, 978842450707, p. 117</ref> He is not listed among the carloctavistas forming the camp of subsequent carloctavista claimants,<ref>Alcalá 2012, pp. 354-363</ref> those reconciling with Don Javier,<ref>Alcalá 2012, p. 370</ref> or those joining Don Juan.<ref>Alcalá 2012, p. 386</ref> though in the 1960s it was noted that he "había mostrado inclinación hacia los javieristas"<ref>Mercedes Vázquez de Prada, ''El final de una ilusión. Auge y declive del tradicionalismo carlista (1957-1967)'', Madrid 2016, {{ISBN|9788416558407}}, p. 135</ref>
==Between ''franquismo'' and ''carlismo''== [[File:Francisco Franco 1959 (cropped).jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Francisco Franco]]]] Del Burgo’s access to the carloctavista camp made him reconsider his stand versus Francoism, as Don Carlos Pio pursued a decisively collaborationist strategy.<ref>by some scholars Carlos VIII is indeed considered an invention of Franco, see Clemente 1995, pp. 115-118</ref> In 1942, during the proceeding fragmentation and bewilderment of Navarrese Carlism,<ref>Aurora Villanueva Martínez, ''Organizacion, actividad y bases del carlismo navarro durante el primer franquismo'' [in:] ''Geronimo de Uztariz'' 19 (2003), pp. 108-109</ref> he stood on the carloctavista ticket in local elections to the Pamplona council and was successful, serving as [[:es:Teniente de alcalde|teniende de alcalde]] until 1944.<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008; at that time the alcalde was a Carlist, Antonio Archanco Zubiri, "comerciante local con la tendencia colaboracionista", María del Mar Larraza-Micheltorena, ''Alcaldes de Pamplona durante el franquismo: Un retrato de conjunto'', [in:] ''Memoria y Civilización'' 15 (2012), pp. 232, 235</ref> By this token, in 1943 and 1944 he performed the prestigious sanfermines task of setting off [[:es:Sanfermines#El chupinazo|el chupinazo]].<ref>see ''sanfermin.com'' site available [http://www.sanfermin.com/index.php/es/la-fiesta/txupinazo/lanzadores-del-txupinazo here]</ref> The council role did necessarily imply collaboration, but promotion to [[colonel]], 1943 appointment as a provincial Falangist delegate for communication and transport and vice secretary of FET Educación Popular section<ref>Aurora Villanueva Martínez, ''El Carlismo navarro durante el primer franquismo: 1937-1951'', Madrid 1998, {{ISBN|9788487863714}}, p. 548</ref> clearly did, especially that in the mid-1940s he openly started to advocate a possibilist policy.<ref>Recommending "beneficio de la impresa comun de salvar a España a las órdenes del Generalísmo Franco", see his letter of 1945 quoted by Alcalá 2012, p. 287</ref> As in 1949 the Falangist zealot [[Luis Valero Bermejo]] was appointed a new provincial civil governor<ref>Maria del Mar Larazza Micheltorena, Alvaro Baraibar Etxeberria, ''La Navarra sotto il Franchismo: la lotta per il controllo provinciale tra i governatori civili e la Diputacion Foral (1945-1955)'', [in:] ''Nazioni e Regioni'', Bari 2013, pp. 101-120</ref> del Burgo was his man of trust,<ref>Alvaro Baraibar Etxeberria, ''Una visión falangista de la foralidad navarra'', [in:] ''Gerónimo de Uztariz'' 2006, p. 11</ref> though when himself offered the jobs of civil governor of [[Lerida]] and [[Lugo]] he declined, claiming that he would never accept a post beyond Navarre.<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05, Garralda Arizcun 2009</ref> In 1950 he assumed the role of a provincial ministerial delegate for tourism and information. When the carloctavista collaborationism crashed with the death of Don Carlos Pio,<ref>some scholars claim that carloctavismo was fractured even earlier, with the 1950 appearance of Juntas Ofensivas de Agitación Carloctavista by Cora y Lira, the carloctavistas which opposed collaboration with Franco, Alcalá 2012, p. 330</ref> del Burgo was left disoriented.
In the mid-1950s it was the mainstream Carlism which in turn commenced a possibilist strategy, with intransigence abandoned and Fal replaced by [[José María Valiente Soriano|Valiente]]. None of the sources consulted offers any information on a would-be rapprochement (or hostility) between del Burgo and the [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Javieristas]], though his ''Ideario'' still served as their doctrinal point of reference.<ref>for 1949 see Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 331, for 1964 see Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias: el carlismo, 1962-1977'', Pamplona 1997, {{ISBN|8431315644}}, 9788431315641, p. 45</ref> In 1958 he was appointed as representative of Navarre in the Falangist [[:es:Consejo Nacional del Movimiento|Consejo Nacional]], a largely fictitious executive body which nevertheless automatically guaranteed membership in the Francoist quasi-parliament, [[Cortes Españolas]];<ref>see ''Indice Historice de Diputados'' service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2817580%29.NDIP here]. For his appointment to Consejo Nacional see ''ABC'' 14.05.58, available [http://hemeroteca.sevilla.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1958/05/14/024.html here]</ref> it is not clear what if any background mechanism elevated him to the position. Del Burgo served in [[Comisión de Leyes Fundamentales]],<ref>''ABC'' 03.06.58, available [http://hemeroteca.abcdesevilla.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1958/06/03/024.html here]</ref> though there is no information available on his stand versus the constitutional laws discussed. Though re-appointed in 1961,<ref>see ''Indice Historice de Diputados'' service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2817580%29.NDIP here].</ref> he did not have his ticket prolonged in 1964; according to some sources, he resigned due to differences with Francoism.<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05, Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> [[File:Charles-Hugues de Bourbon-Parme.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Don Carlos Hugo]]]] As a former radical aetista and an active collaborationist, he would have seemed a potential ally for the new generation of Carlist progressists, also revolutionary, socially-minded, AET members and apparently keen to exploit possibilist opportunities within Francoism. However, they preferred to jump on the older version of [[Juan Vázquez de Mella|de Mella’s]] sociedalismo and there is no trace of any link between del Burgo and the [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|hugocarlistas]].<ref>compare Martorell Pérez 2009</ref> One source suggests that as Delegado del Ministerio de Información y Turismo he sabotaged their plans, preventing the presence of [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Carlos Hugo]] at the annual [[Montejurra]] gathering in 1964.<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 306; this version is not confirmed in Javier Lavardín [José Antonio Parilla], ''Historia del ultimo pretendiente a la corona de España'', Paris 1976, pp. 231-234</ref> Del Burgo is not mentioned as taking part in power struggle between Traditionalists and Progressists, which erupted within Carlism in the late 1960s,<ref>the most competent study on the issue, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, barely mentions del Burgo; another detailed study on Carlist ideological identity of the 1960s, Martorell Pérez 2009, refers to del Burgo only as a source</ref> though he maintained at least private contacts with Traditionalists like Manuel Fal Conde in 1969.<ref>"Lo único que he hecho en mi vida -y voy en los 56- ha sido trabajar para crear una familia a imagen y semejanza de la de mis mayores, y perpetuar en mis hijos -con éxito- las ideas y actitudes que en nosotros son ya tradicionales", a letter from del Burgo to Fal, quoted after Gemma Pierola Narvarte, Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''Entre la ideología y lo cotidiano: la familia en el carlismo y el tradicionalismo (1940-1975)'', [in:] ''Vasconia: cuadernos de historia-geografía'' 28 (1999), p. 52; Fal also appreciated del Burgo, see Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''Navarra 1937-1939: el fiasco de la Unificación'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 69 (2008), p. 439. In the early 1970s a "Jaime del Burgo" considered launching a post-Carlist regionalist political grouping, though it is unclear whether the person in question is the father or the son, see José Miguel Orts Timoner, ''Recuerdo de José Ángel Zubaiur Alegre'', [in:] ''Portal Avant!'' 20.04.12, available [http://www.carlistes.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=321:2012recuerdozubiaur&catid=25:opinionpolitica&Itemid=56 here]</ref>
==Public servant== [[File:La Agrícola.JPG|thumbnail|left|[[:es:Biblioteca General de Navarra|Biblioteca General]] site 1972-2010]] Already in May 1936 del Burgo won the contest for the job of an auxiliar at [[Archivo de la Diputación Foral de Navarra]].<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05, Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> Following the Civil War pause, in 1939 he resumed the civil servant career; at that time the provincial Navarrese government decided to detach the existing [[Biblioteca de Navarra]] from [[Instituto de Segunda Enseñanza]] and establish it as a stand-alone [[:es:Biblioteca General de Navarra|Biblioteca General de Navarra]]; del Burgo became the first head and organizer of the new unit.<ref>''ABC'' 25.10.05, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2005/10/25/044.html here]</ref> He remained at its helm for the next 43 years,<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> presiding over its opening in 1941, removal from [[:es:Biblioteca General de Navarra|Consejo Foral]] building to "La Agrícola" on Plaza de San Fernando in 1972<ref>see Biblioteca y Filmoteca de Navarra leaflet, available [http://www.navarra.es/NR/rdonlyres/AF46F2DC-F676-47C9-B583-C3C74B0AD76E/177823/BibliotecaNavarra.pdf here]</ref> and re-formatting it from a scholarly institute to the Navarrese public library.<ref>removal to the new modern site at Paseo de Antonio Pérez Goyena took place in 2010</ref> On top of this job, in 1941 del Burgo became head of [[Red de Bibliotecas de Navarra]],<ref>see ''Institucion Principe de Viana'' entry at ''Gran Enciclopedia Navarra'', available [http://www.enciclopedianavarra.com/navarra/institucion-principe-de-viana/9508/2/ here]; the job coincided with 1943 appointment to vicesecretario de Educación Popular de FET, Villanueva Martínez 1998, p. 548</ref> the provincial network of local libraries, in course of his service having opened 65 public libraries across the province.<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref> Until the late 20th century he remained active in professional archivist and librarian organizations.<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> [[File:Montejurra and graffiti.JPG|thumbnail|[[Camino de Santiago]] and [[Montejurra]]]] In 1950 del Burgo became the provincial delegate of Ministry of Information and Tourism.<ref>see ''Noticias de Navarra'' site available [http://pagebuilder2.deia.com/foro/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=18123&start=0 here]</ref> At this position he acted as head of the Navarrese Francoist [[censorship]] office, banning a number of films, theatric performances, books and songs;<ref>see ''Noticias de Navarra'' forum available [http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/foro/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=18123&start=30 here]</ref> he is particularly remembered for censoring the marketing campaign of ''[[The Mark of Zorro (1940 film)|The Mark of Zorro]]'' movie;<ref>the issue is not entirely clear, as the movie entered Spain in the early 1940s, long before del Burgo assumed the Navarrese censorship duties</ref> the original advertising slogan, "El Zorro, friend of the poor, feared by tyrants" apparently sounded too hazardous for the regime.<ref>"El Zorro, amigo de los pobres, adorado por las mujeres, idolatrado por los hombres, temido por los tiranos!", quoted after ''Noticias de Navarra'' site available [http://www.noticiasdenavarra.com/foro/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=18123&start=30 here]</ref> In 1964 del Burgo left the ministry and assumed the job of Director de Turismo, Bibliotecas y Cultura Popular de la Diputación Foral de Navarra.<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05; other sources claim he commenced in 1966, Garralda Arizcun 2008; for a sample of his engagement in Pyrenaic tourism see ''La Vanguardia'' 21.03.65, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1965/03/21/pagina-33/33555554/pdf.html here]</ref> Having been responsible for mass culture, he edited and published around 400 popular brochures<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref> - writing some of them himself - and organized hundreds of cultural events, mostly highlighting traditionalist values at the expense of democratic ones.<ref>he also contributed to and took part in nationwide cultural initiatives, like centenary celebrations of Vazquez de Mella, see ''La Vanguardia'' 18.03.61, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1965/03/21/pagina-35/32693194/pdf.html here]</ref> By some sources he is described as periodista.<ref>''ABC'' 25.10.05, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2005/10/25/044.html here]; other sources claim del Burgo did not try his hand in periodsmo, Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> As head of tourism del Burgo promoted the province across Spain, developed the Navarrese section of [[El Camino de Santiago]], drafted ''Ordenación Turística'' (1964) for the entire trail<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> and wrote tourist guides related to Navarre.<ref>e.g. ''Planificación turística de Navarra'' (1962), ''Recursos turísticos de Navarra'' (1964), ''El Pirineo navarro'' (1977), ''Navarra'' (1978), ''Pamplona'' (1978), ''Olite'' (1978), ''Guía de Navarra'' (1982) and other</ref> Since the late 1960s he was also director of [[Escuela Municipal de Artes aplicadas y Oficios artístico]]s.<ref>''ABC'' 25.10.05; compare Escuela Municipal de Artes aplicadas y Oficios artísticos website, available [http://www.escueladeartepamplona.com/?page_id=8 here]</ref> Resigned from all public posts in 1982, a month before his 70th birthday.<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref>
==Historian== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] As a historian del Burgo focused on – if not limited himself to – Carlism and Navarre, with a clear preference for the 19th and 20th centuries and for the history of [[Fuero|foralism]]. His works range from syntheses to monographs, biographies and case studies. As an amateur with no systematic training, he did not adhere to any specific methodology,<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> though he remained chiefly within the limits of political history and based his studies on thorough research in primary sources, mostly the printed ones.
Del Burgo’s key historical work is the monumental ''Bibliografía de las guerras carlistas'' (1953-1966), the opus which spanned across 5 volumes, cost 25 years of work<ref>it was this work which earned del Burgo the national literary prize in 1967, Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> and indexed more that 10,000 works; until today it remains a point of reference for all students of the subject.<ref>see e.g. José María Sanchez Nistal, ''Problemas y soluciones para la busqueda de información bibliografica en la investigación historica'', [in:] ''Probemas actuales de la historia'', Salamanca 1993, {{ISBN|847481734X}}, 9788474817348, p. 15</ref> Second to be listed is ''Historia General de Navarra'' (1978), a massive synthesis of the region’s past, heavily based on his earlier works and the result of 10-year-research.<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008; later Jaime Ignacio del Burgo Tajadura re-worked the volume and re-issued as a joint work, see ''Vanity Fair'' review available [http://www.revistavanityfair.es/articulos/historia-de-navarra-el-libro-de-jaime-ignacio-del-burgo/17081 here]</ref> Then come detailed studies related to the history of Carlism and Navarre, most prominent of them ''Carlos VII y su tiempo'' (1994) and ''La sucesión de Carlos II'' (1967). Del Burgo is also the author of ''Conspiración y guerra civil'' (1970), the work intended as a synthesis, though today it is – somewhat unintentionally – broadly used rather as a historical source.<ref>compare numerous references in Martorell Pérez 2009</ref> Finally, he authored a number of minor publications ranging from petty contributions to popular booklets,<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> like ''Vida y hechos militares del mariscal de campo Don Juan Manuel Sarasa narrados por él mismo''.<ref>co-authored with Juan Manuel Sarasa</ref> Many of his works form part of auxiliary sciences, bibliography or [[metabibliography]], [[source criticism]], or [[prosopography]].<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008, selected bibliography in Ainhoa Arozamena Ayala, Cristina Aznar Munárri, ''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/34128 here]</ref>
As a historian del Burgo is praised for sound referential basis;<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> the critics usually point to his Carlist bias.<ref>José Luís Martínez Sanz, ''Historians and Historiography on carlismo: the difficult boundary between politics and science'', [in:] ''Contributions'' 49 (2002), p. 115; he is also denounced for pursuing an utopian vision of a Navarrese-Carlist unity, as according to him, the Carlist wars "configuraron de manera permanente el caracter de esta region, asignandole el papel de defensora de las mas puras esencias hispanicas", quoted after Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''Navarra y el carlismo durante el régimen de Franco: la utopía de la identidad unitaria'', [in:] ''Investigaciones históricas'' 17 (1997), p. 287-8</ref> He is particularly criticized for an attempt to recalculate the number of victims of the [[White Terror (Spain)|Rightist terror]] in Navarre; other historians support 4 times higher figures.<ref>Del Burgo arrived at a total of ca 680 victims, while the figure advanced by many others is in the range of 2,000-3,000, compare José María Jimeno Jurío, ''La Gierra Civil en Navarra (1936-1939)'', Pamplona 2006, {{ISBN|9788476814826}}, [[Ramón Salas Larrazábal]], ''Los Fusilados en Navarra en la Guerra de 1936'', Madrid 1983, {{ISBN|843980024X}}, Mari Jose Berrio Zaratiegui, Juan Carlos Esparza Zabalegi, José Mari Ruiz Vilas, ''Navarra 1936 - de la Esperanza al terror'', Altafulla 2003, {{ISBN|9788493095796}}</ref> This controversy coincides with the fact that del Burgo was personally accused of a war crime,<ref>see the account of Francisco Inza Goñi in ''Navarra 1936 - de la Esperanza al terror'', p. 483, widely quoted in cyberspace, compare [http://old.kaosenlared.net/noticia/requetes-tradicion-sanguinaria here]</ref> the charge that left him very embittered<ref>according to del Burgo’s own account the case was exactly the opposite: he did his best to prevent war crimes, e.g. saving republican POWs from execution by incorporating them into requeté units, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 85</ref> and which he always denied;<ref>"Del Burgo, mientras vivió, dijo una y otra vez a quien le quiso oir que no había matado a nadie fuera del campo de batalla y mucho menos en Pamplona" quoted after ''kaosenlared.net'' available [http://old.kaosenlared.net/noticia/requete-sinecdoque-edgar-gonzalez here]</ref> it is also disqualified by some historians.<ref>moreover, some claim he saved lives of Leftist activists like Telesforo Monzon or Juan Arrastia, see EKA site available [https://web.archive.org/web/20060902172409/http://www.eka-partidocarlista.com/delburgo.htm here], Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 117</ref> As an amateur he has never assumed academic duties,<ref>Ainhoa Arozamena Ayala, Cristina Aznar Munárri, ''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' refer to him as "profesor mercantil", though no trace of his academic or otherwise teaching activity is found elsewhere</ref> though he became member-correspondent of [[:es:Real Academia de la Historia|Real Academia de la Historia]];<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05, Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> for his bibliographical work del Burgo received the [[National Literary Prize (Francoist Spain)|National Literary Prize]] in 1967.<ref>''ABC'' 25.10.05, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/2005/10/25/044.html here]</ref>
==Writer== [[File:Larrau to Salazar.JPG|thumbnail|left|a valley in Navarrese Pyrenees]] Del Burgo commenced his literary career in the early 1930s, publishing short [[drama]]s revolving around episodes from the Carlist history and sometimes played at the local party circulos: ''Lealtad'' (1932), ''Cruzados'' (1934) and ''Al borde de la traición'' (1936).<ref>Ainhoa Arozamena Ayala, Cristina Aznar Munárri, ''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''</ref> Calibrated as praises of old Carlist virtues and with clear moralizing objectives,<ref>Ainhoa Arozamena Ayala, Cristina Aznar Munárri, ''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', Ugarte Tellería 1998, p. 278, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 211; according to Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''"Esa ciudad maldita, cuna del centralismo, la burocracia y el liberalismo": la ciudad como enemigo en el tradicionalismo español'', [in:] ''Actas del congreso internacional "Arquitectura, ciudad e ideología antiurbana'', Pamplona 2002, {{ISBN|8489713510}}, p. 92, del Burgo’s dramas were "ejemplos de teatro carlista tradicionalista"</ref> they are classified as costumbrismo nostalgico.<ref>"todos ellos coinciden en reflejar en sus obras cómo la perniciosa influencia de lo foráneo va pervirtiendo las sanas y católicas costumbres locales de la Navarra ‘auténtica’", Javier Dronda Martínez, ''Con Cristo o contra Cristo. Religión y movilización antirrepublicana en navarra (1931-1936)'', Tafalla 2013, {{ISBN|8415313314}}, 9788415313311, p. 22</ref> In 1937 he tried his hand as a poet with ''En Pos. Ensayo poético''.<ref>Ainhoa Arozamena Ayala, Cristina Aznar Munárri, ''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'' claim it was published 1927, which is probably a typo and should read 1937, see Jaime del Burgo, ''Catalogo bio-bibliografico'', Pamplona 1954, p. 275, available [http://dialnet.unirioja.es/descarga/articulo/2253350.pdf here]</ref> Following the Civil War break del Burgo switched to [[novel]]s: ''El valle perdido'' (1942), ''Huracán'' (1943) and ''Lo que buscamos'' (1951).<ref>Ainhoa Arozamena Ayala, Cristina Aznar Munárri, ''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''</ref> Set in the history of the Civil War, the first two were designed to acclaim patriotic merits and presented a traditional narrative style, though with plots accommodating magical threads;<ref>''El valle perdido'' plot features two Navarrese nationalist pilots who crash-landed somewhere in the Pyrenees, finding themselves in a valley cut off from the outer world and inhabited by descendants of those fighting in the 19th-century Carlist wars</ref> the third one assumed a different tone, infected with bitterness and naturalism.<ref>Piotr Sawicki, ''La narrativa española de la Guerra Civil (1936-1975). Propaganda, testimonio y memoria creativa'', Alicante 2010, p. 240</ref> After the break of the 1960s and 1970s, dedicated mostly to historical research, del Burgo returned to drama with ''Llamada sin respuesta'' (1978), to poetry with ''Soliloquios: en busca de un rayo de luz perdido'' (1998)<ref>Ainhoa Arozamena Ayala, Cristina Aznar Munárri, ''Jaime del Burgo Torres'' entry, [in:] ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''; the sub-title is a commentary to del Burgo losing his eyesight in the last years of his life, Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> and to prose with ''La Cruz del fuego'' (2000), a well-documented adventurous intrigue from the times of [[Henry I of Navarre]].<ref>Carlos Mata-Indurain 2002, p. 935</ref>
Though hevaily contributing to [[Carlism in literature]], Del Burgo has not made it to the history of Spanish belles-lettres of the 20th century, be it either general synthetic accounts<ref>Del Burgo is entirely missing in synthesis of Spanish literature like Santos Sanz Villanueva, ''Historia y crítica de la literatura española'', vol. 8/1 (''Epoca contemporanea 1939-1975''), Barcelona 1999, {{ISBN|8474237815}}, Domingo Yndurain, ''Historia y critica de la literatura española 1939-1980'', vol. 8 (''Epoca contemporanea 1939-1980''), Barcelona 1981, Jordi Gracia, Domingo Ródenas, ''Derrota y restitución de la modernidad: literatura contemporánea, 1939-2009'', Madrid 2009, {{ISBN|9788498921229}}, [[Jean Canavaggio]], ''Historia de la literatura española'', vol. 6 (''El siglo XX''), Barcelona 1995, {{ISBN|843447459X}}</ref> or encyclopedias and dictionaries.<ref>compare Jesus Bregante, ''Diccionario espasa. Literatura española'', Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|8467012722}}, Ricardo Gullon (ed.), ''Diccionario de Literatura Española y Hispanoamericana'', vol. 1, Madrid 1993, {{ISBN|8420652482}}</ref> He is missing even in detailed studies on the Francoist era novels.<ref>Santos Sanz Villanueva, ''La novela española durante el franquismo'', Madrid 2010, {{ISBN|9788424904180}}, Ignacio Soldevila Durante, ''Historia de la novela española 1936-2000'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|8437619114}}</ref> His prose is classified as falling into the "novela de la guerra civil española" category. Appreciated for documentary value, del Burgo’s novels are described as production of scarce esthetic and literary value, very repetitive in terms of its structures, primitive in terms of narration and [[Manichaean]] in terms of personalities.<ref>Carlos Mata, ''La aportación de Navarra a la literatura española'', [in:] Jaime Ignacio del Burgo (ed.), ''Vascos y Navarros en la Historia de Espana'', Pamplona 2007, {{ISBN|9788495643025}}, p. 366</ref> Present-day scholars point to two interesting features of his novels. One is a strong [[Basque people|Basque]] ethnic sentiment, calibrated in pre-nationalist, [[Sabino Arana|sabinan]] terms of an ancient Basque Eden.<ref>Francisco Javier Caspistegui, ''Historia oral, inmaterial e intrahistoria en la recuperación de la memoria colectiva de la Navarra rural'', [in:] ''Gerónimo de Uztariz'' 23-24 (2008), p. 211; Basque threads were present though not key in many of his works; in fact, he insisted on different ethnic origins of alaveses, vizcainos, guipuzcoanos and navarros, see Iñaki Iriarte López, ''Euskaros, nacionalistas y navarristas. Ideologías del pacto y la agonía en Navarra'', [in:] ''Revista Internacional de los Estudios Vascos'' 44 (1999), p. 59</ref> Another is equally idyllic rustic thread, advancing a fairly typical Carlist praise of ruralismo and mistrust towards urban life.<ref>Caspistegui Gorasurreta 2002, pp. 80-81</ref> [[File:Insignia of the Commander Grades of the Civil Order of Alfonso X, the Wise.svg|thumbnail|180px|[[Order of Alfonso X the Wise]]]] Del Burgo’s novelist work was acknowledged by [[Premio de Literatura y Periodismo de la Secretaria General de FET]] (1954).<ref>''ABC'' 23.12.54, available [http://hemeroteca.abcdesevilla.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1954/12/23/009.html here]</ref> Apart from the national prize of 1967, he was also rewarded by the [[Bayonne-Pamplona International Competition Award]] (1963),<ref>Garralda Arizcun 2008</ref> [[Fundacion de Larramendi Award]] (1993)<ref>see Fundación Ignacio Larramendi site, available [http://www.larramendi.es/i18n/consulta/resultados_navegacion.cmd?busq_autoridadesbib=FILA20090027916 here]</ref> and [[Badge of the Order of Alfonso X the Wise]] (1997), conceded by the Ministry of Education and received in Pamplona in May 1999 from the then Minister of Education and Culture, [[Mariano Rajoy]].<ref>''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref> Permanent Councilor of [[Institución Príncipe de Viana]],<ref>''El Mundo'' 26.10.05, available [http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2005/10/24/obituarios/1130148092.html here]</ref> himself he has never received the [[:es:Premios Internacionales de Navarra Príncipe de Viana|Viana Cultural Prize]], set up in 1990 and awarded by the [[:es:Gobierno de Navarra|Government of Navarre]].<ref>though was nominated in 2001, ''Diario de Navarra'' 25.10.05</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=March 2010}} {{Infobox Historic building |image = Cetinje palace.jpg |caption = King Nikola's Palace, former royal palace of Montenegro |location_town = [[Cetinje]] |location_country = [[Montenegro]] |architect = [[Dragislav Jakotić]] |client = |engineer = |construction_start_date = 1863 |completion_date = 1867 |date_demolished = |cost = |structural_system = |style = [[Neoclassicism]] }} '''[[Nicholas I of Montenegro|King Nikola's]] Palace''' is located in [[Cetinje]], [[Montenegro]], and for more than 50 years served as the seat of the Montenegrin Royal family. In 1926 it became a museum, from 1980 it was one of the departments of [[National Museum of Montenegro]].
The small palace was built from 1863 to 1867 in a simple style typical of Cetinje houses with certain elements of [[neoclassicism]]. The interiors were designed in style of [[Historicism (art)|Historicism]] and [[Art Nouveau]].
In the entrance hall are exposed the [[Montenegrin crown jewels]], which are the most popular exhibition of the National museum.
'''The Royal Garden''' was built in 1870 as a pine alley. Gardens were refurbished in 1971. There are many flower beds with crocuses, geraniums, tulips and rose and jasmine bushes.
In the back of garden there is cedar grove with domimant villa with small summer-house, which served fas a guest house for foreign visitors.

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} A monarch is the person who heads a [[monarchy]], usually reigning for life, or until [[abdication]] or [[Deposition (politics)|deposition]]. The reign of some monarchs has been notably short. Many of these monarchs acceded to the throne as a result of being first in an order of succession, while other monarchs claimed the throne as a result of some conflict. The authenticity of some monarchs has been disputed, especially those who reigned during conflict. One factor in such debates is whether the monarch held the throne in a symbolic or nominal capacity. Two examples are *King [[Louis-Antoine, Duke of Angouleme|Louis XIX]] of France, who succeeded upon the abdication of [[Charles X of France|Charles X]] only to abdicate in favour of [[Henri, comte de Chambord|Henry V]] instead of assuming the throne, and *Emperor [[Michael II of Russia]], who succeeded on the abdication of [[Nicholas II]] only to abdicate himself in favor of nobody. ==Obscure monarchs thought to have reigned less than a year== ''Note: Some of the following have been disputed as genuine monarchs'' {| class="wikitable" ! | Name ! | Country

Due to the unpopularity of the new Empire he reverted to being the president of the Republic of China until his death on 5 June 1916. |- |Despot [[Stephen Tomašević]] |[[Serbia]] | |1 April 1459 |20 June 1459 |2 months, 20 days |Became despot of Serbia to unite forces with Bosnia, but shortly after taking power, he agrees to leave Serbia to the Ottomans. |- | King [[Pedro I of Brazil|Pedro IV]] | [[Kingdom of Portugal|Portugal]] | [[House of Braganza|Braganza]] | 10 March 1826 | 28 May 1826 | 2 months, 18 days | Became the first [[Empire of Brazil|Emperor of Brazil]] in 1822 after declaring that country's [[Independence of Brazil|independence]] from Portugal. Succeeded the Portuguese throne with the death of his father, [[John VI of Portugal|João VI]], but abdicated in favour of his daughter, [[Maria II of Portugal|Maria II]], in the awareness that a reunion of Brazil and Portugal would be unacceptable to the people of both nations. He abdicated the Brazilian throne in 1831, in favour of his son [[Pedro II of Brazil|Pedro II]]. |- | King [[Edward V of England|Edward V]] | [[England]] | [[House of York|York]] | 9 April 1483 | 25 June 1483 | 2 months, 16 days | Succeeded with the death of his father, [[Edward IV of England|Edward IV]]. Deposed after he and his brother [[Richard of Shrewsbury, Duke of York|Richard, Duke of York]], were declared illegitimate; their uncle then ascended the throne as [[Richard III of England|Richard III]]. The young princes [[Princes in the Tower|disappeared from the Tower of London]] later in 1483. |- | width="16%" | King [[Philip I of Castile|Philip I]] | width="10%" | [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]] ([[Spain]]) | width="12%" | [[Habsburg]] | width="12%" | 12 July 1506 | width="12%" | 25 September 1506 | width="10%" | 2 months, 13 days | width="28%" | Declared his wife, the sovereign Queen Joanna I, insane in order to rule in her place. He then died, apparently of typhoid fever, although rumors claimed he was poisoned by King Ferdinand of Aragon. |- | [[Seventh Dynasty of Egypt]] (usually considered spurious) | [[Ancient Egypt]] | [[Seventh Dynasty of Egypt]] | c. 2180 BC | c. 2180 BC | 70 days | According to [[Sextus Julius Africanus|Africanus]] (c. AD 160-240), [[Manetho]] (3rd century BC) claims that 70 kings reigned for a total of 70 days. |- | [[Ibrahim ibn al-Walid]] | [[Umayyad Caliphate]] | [[Umayad|Umayyad, Marwanid branch]] | 744 | 744 | 70 days | |- | Emperor [[Alexios V Doukas]] | [[Byzantine Empire]] | [[Doukas]] | 5 February 1204 | 12 April 1204 | 2 months, 7 days | Seized the throne after overthrowing and imprisoning [[Alexios IV Angelos]], whose father and co-emperor, [[Isaac II Angelos]], died at around the same time. His decision to have Alexios IV killed angered the army of the [[Fourth Crusade]], who ultimately [[Sack of Constantinople (1204)|sacked Constantinople]]. Alexios V fled to [[Mosynopolis]], where he was blinded on the orders of his father-in-law, the previously deposed [[Alexios III Angelos]], before being brought back to Constantinople and executed for treason. |- | width="16%" | Emperor [[Didius Julianus]] | width="10%" | [[Roman Empire]] | width="12%" | [[Year of the Five Emperors]] | width="12%" | 28 March 193 | width="12%" | 1 June 193 | width="10%" | 2 months, 5 days | width="28%" | Purchased the throne after the [[Praetorian Guards]] auctioned it off. Faced revolt by General [[Septimius Severus]] who captured and executed him. |- | King [[Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse|Frederick Charles]] | [[Kingdom of Finland (1918)|Finland]] | [[House of Hesse-Kassel|Hesse-Kassel]] | 9 October 1918 | 14 December 1918 | 2 months, 5 days | Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse was elected king by the newly independent Kingdom of Finland and due to German defeat in the First World War renounced his title without travelling to his own kingdom. |- | King [[Mamia III Gurieli]] | King of [[Kingdom of Imereti|Imereti]] | [[Gurieli]] | November 1713 | 5 January 1714 | ≈2 months | reigned for around a year (1701–1702), eight months (October 1711 – June 1712), three months (November 1713-5 January 1714) |- | Chúa [[Trịnh Cán]] | [[Vietnam]] | [[Trịnh Lords|Trịnh]] | 1782 | 1782 | ≈2 months | Trịnh Cán succeeded his father [[Trịnh Sâm]] to the throne aged 6 years and his half brother [[Trịnh Khải]] soon killed him and usurped his throne. |- | Duke [[Joachim Ernst, Duke of Anhalt|Joachim Ernst]] | [[Duchy of Anhalt|Anhalt]] | [[House of Ascania|Ascania]] | 13 September 1918 | 12 November 1918 | 1 month, 30 days | Succeeded with the death of his father, Eduard (above). Abdicated during the [[German Revolution of 1918–19|German Revolution]] at the end of the First World War, with the Duchy then becoming the [[Free State of Anhalt]]. Died in [[Buchenwald concentration camp]] in 1947, as a prisoner of the Soviet Union. |- | King [[Bolesław I the Brave|Bolesław I Chrobry]] | [[Poland]] | [[Piast dynasty|Piast]] | 18 April 1025 | 17 June 1025 | 1 month, 30 days | Duke of Poland from 992; crowned himself King in 1025. Died not long after his coronation, most likely due to an illness. |- | King [[Edgar Ætheling|Edgar II]] | [[Kingdom of England]] | [[House of Wessex|Wessex]] | 15 October 1066 | 10 December 1066 | 1 month, 25 days | Grandson of [[Edmund Ironside|Edmund II]] (above). Elected king by the [[Witenagemot]] following the death of Harold II at the Battle of Hastings but never crowned; subsequently submitted to [[William the Conqueror]]. |- | King [[Charles III of Naples|Charles II]] | [[Kingdom of Hungary (1301–1526)|Hungary]] | [[Capetian House of Anjou]] | 31 December 1385 | 24 February 1386 | 1 month, 24 days | After the death of [[Louis I of Hungary|Louis I]], he had claimed the Hungarian throne as the senior Angevin male, and ousted Louis' daughter [[Mary, Queen of Hungary|Mary]] in December 1385. He was murdered in February 1386. |- | Tsar [[Feodor II of Russia|Feodor II]] | All Russia | Godunov | 23 April 1605 | 20 June 1605 | 1 month, 22 days | Tsar Feodor II succeeded to the throne after the death of his father [[Boris Godunov]] and was soon after killed during the [[Time of Troubles]]. |- | Emperor [[Ziying]] | [[China]] | | mid-October 207 BC | December 207 BC | 1 month, 16 days | [[Ziying]] was the last ruler of the [[Qin Dynasty]] of [[China]] |- | Sultan [[Al-Mansur Abu Bakr]] | [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluk Egypt]] | | 17 June 1341 | 5 August 1341 | 49 days | He was deposed and arrested by his father's senior emir, [[Qawsun]]. After being sent to prison, he was executed on Qawsun's orders two months later. |- | Emperor [[Rinchinbal Khan, Emperor Ningzong of Yuan|Ningzong]] | [[China]] | | c. 1332 | c. 1332 | 1 month, 13 days | [[Ningzong]] was briefly installed as Emperor of the [[Yuan Dynasty]], a ruling [[dynasties in Chinese history|dynasty]] of [[China]]. |- | [[Tirigan]] | [[Sumer]] | Dynasty of [[Gutian dynasty of Sumer|Guti]] | c. 2050 BC | c. 2050 BC | 40 days | Last king of Guti, according to the [[Sumerian King List]]. |->a | Khan [[Umor of Bulgaria|Umor]] | [[First Bulgarian Empire]] | Dynasty of [[Uokil]] | 766 | 766 | 40 days | |- | King [[Sweyn Forkbeard|Sweyn I]] | England | | 25 December 1013 | 3 February 1014 | 1 month, 9 days | King of Denmark from c. 985; also ruled most of Norway. Seized the English throne from [[Æthelred the Unready|Æthelred II]] following a successful invasion of the country; Æthelred regained the throne following Sweyn's death. Sweyn's son, [[Cnut the Great|Canute]], ruled England from 1016 to 1035. |- | King [[Umberto II of Italy|Umberto II]] | [[Italy]] | [[House of Savoy|Savoy]] | 9 May 1946 | 12 June 1946 | 1 month, 3 days | Ascended the throne when his father, [[Victor Emmanuel III]], abdicated in an attempt to strengthen support for the monarchy against a [[Italian institutional referendum, 1946|referendum to abolish it]]. After the referendum passed and a republic was declared, Umberto left Italy and never returned. |- | Emperor [[Li Zicheng]] | [[China]] | [[Shun Dynasty|Li]] | 25 April 1644 | 27 May 1644 | 1 month, 2 days | [[Li Zicheng]] declared himself Emperor of China after [[Chongzhen Emperor|Chongzhen]] committed suicide and was then forced from power after the [[Battle of Shanhai Pass]]. |- | [[Pope John Paul I]] | [[Holy See]] | | 26 August 1978 | 28 September 1978 | 1 month, 2 days | |- | [[Pope Benedict V]] | [[Holy See]] | | 22 May 964 | 23 June 964 | 1 month, 1 day | |- | King [[Reccared II]] | King of [[Hispania]], [[Septimania]] and [[Kingdom of Galicia|Galicia]] | [[Visigoths]] | 612 | 612 | ≈1 month | |- | King [[Shallum of Israel]] | [[Israel]] | | 773 BC''Annals of the World'' by James Ussher, section 569 | c. 772 BC | 1 month2 Kings 15:13 | Biblical King from the [[Second Book of Kings]]. Because he became King in the 38th year but died in the 39th year, then his reign probably spans the [[Jewish Calendar|Jewish New year]]. |} ==Less than a month== ''Note: Some of the following have Óláfsson]] | [[Kingdom of Mann and the Isles]] | [[Crovan dynasty]] | 6 May 1249 | 30 May 1249 | 24 days | Slain by an apparent accomplice of his first cousin once removed, [[Haraldr Guðrøðarson]], a ([[Pope#Shortest-reigning popes|See full list]]) |- | King [[Louis II of Holland|Lodewijk II]] | [[Kingdom of Holland|Holland]] | [[House of Bonaparte|Bonaparte]] | 1 July 1810 | 13 July 1810 | 12 days | Succeeded with the abdication of his father [[Louis Bonaparte|Lodewijk Napoleon]] only to have his kingdom annexed by [[Napoleon I]] of the [[First French Empire|French]]. |- | Emperor [[Puyi]] | [[China]] | [[Qing Dynasty|Qing]] | 1 July 1917 | 12 July 1917 | 12 days | Restored by [[Zhang Xun (Qing loyalist)|Zhang Xun]] in a coup, but the republic was restored by [[Duan Qirui]] 12 days later. |- | [[Lady Jane Grey|Queen Jane]] | [[England]] and [[Ireland]] | [[Tudor dynasty|Tudor]] | 10 July 1553 | 19 July 1553 | 9 days | Proclaimed Queen four days after the death of [[Edward VI of England|Edward VI]] only to be removed and later executed by [[Mary I of England|Mary I]]. |- | Emir [[Saad Al-Abdullah Al-Salim Al-Sabah]] | [[Kuwait]] | [[Al-Sabah]] | 15 January 2006 | 24 January 2006 | 9 days | Succeeded with the death of [[Jaber Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah|Jaber III Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]] and voted out of office by parliament due to ill health before being able to issue his abdication in favour of [[Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah|Sabah IV Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]]. |- | King [[Henri, Count of Chambord|Henry V]] | [[July Monarchy|King of France]] | [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon]] | 2 August 1830 | 9 August 1830 | 7 days | Succeeded with the abdications of his grandfather, [[Charles X of France|Charles X]], and then his uncle, [[Louis Antoine, Duke of Angoulême|Louis XIX]] (below), twenty minutes later. Never officially proclaimed as King, he was rejected by the National Assembly in favour of [[Louis Philippe I|Louis Philippe of Orléans]]. Afterwards, he was the [[Legitimists|Legitimist]] claimant to the throne from 1844 until his death in 1883. |- | King [[Thong Lan]] | [[Ayutthaya Kingdom]] | [[Suphannaphum Dynasty|Suphannaphum]] | 1370 | 1370 | 7 days | Succeeded with the death of [[Borommarachathirat I]] and then [[Ramesuan (king of Ayutthaya)|Ramesuan]]'s forces quickly took the palace and executed King Thong Lan. King Ramesuan then held the throne. |- | King [[Sigeric]] | [[Spain]] | [[Visigoth|Visigothic Kingdom]] | 415 | 415 | 7 days | Usurped the throne after the assassination of king [[Ataulf]], but his cruelty raised high opposition, leading to his murder. |- | King [[Zimri (king)|Zimri]] | [[Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)|Israel]] | | c. 885 BC or c. 876 BC | c. 885 BC or c. 876 BC | 7 days | A biblical king from the [[Books of Kings]]. |} ==Less than a week== ''Note: Some of the following have been disputed as genuine monarchs'' {| class="wikitable" ! width="16%" | Name ! width="10%" | Country ! width="12%" | Royal house/dynasty ! width="12%" | Reign began ! width="12%" | Reign ended ! width="10%" | Length ! width="28%" | Comments |- | King [[John I of France|John I]] | [[France in the Middle Ages|France]] and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] | [[House of Capet|Capet]] | 15 November 1316 | 20 November 1316 | 5 days | Posthumous son of [[Louis X of France|Louis X]], died aged 5 days. |- | King [[Crateuas of Macedon|Crateuas]] | [[Macedon]] | [[Argead Dynasty]] | 399 BC | 399 BC | 4 days | Assassinated [[Archelaus I]] during a hunt.
