The numbering of Stephens from [[Pope Stephen I|Stephen I]] (254–257 AD) to [[Pope Stephen II|Stephen II]] (752–757 AD) skips him over, and he was removed from the 1961 [[List of Popes]]. |- | [[Lê Trung Tông (Early Lê)|Lê Trung Tông]] | [[Vietnam]] | [[Early Lê Dynasty|Lê]] | October 1005 | October 1005 | 3 days | Assassinated by order of his successor [[Lê Ngoạ Triều]]. |- | [[Lê Quang Trị]] | [[Vietnam]] | [[Later Lê Dynasty|Lê]] | 1516 | 1516 | 3 days | |- | King [[Karposh (king)|Karposh]] | [[Kingdom of Kumanovo|Kumanovo]] | | October 1689 | October 1689 | 3 days | Leader of [[Karposh's Rebellion|an uprising]] against the Ottoman Empire. |- | Emperor [[Dục Đức]] | [[Vietnam]] | [[Nguyễn Dynasty|Nguyễn]] | 20 July 1883 | 23 July 1883 | 3 days | Executed for failing to observe Confucian mourning etiquette, and for having intimate relations with his predecessor's concubines. |- | King [[Inayatullah Khan|Inayatullah Khan Seraj]] | [[Afghanistan]] | [[Barakzai]] | 14 January 1929 | 17 January 1929 | 3 days | Inayatullah Khan Seraj replaced his brother King [[Amanullah Khan]] who had abdicated. Inayatullah Khan Seraj then abdicated himself three days later in favour of [[Habibullah Ghazi]] who was deposed 8 months later. |- | King [[Dipendra of Nepal|Dipendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev]] | [[Nepal]] | [[Shah dynasty|Shah]] | 1 June 2001 | 4 June 2001 | <56 hours | Succeeded to the throne after [[patricide|murdering his father]] [[Birendra of Nepal|Birendra]] during the [[Nepalese royal massacre]], in which Dipendra allegedly inflicted mortal wounds upon himself. He was comatose for the duration of his reign. |- | [[King Xiaowen of Qin]] | [[China]] | [[Qin (state)|Qin]] | 13 September 250 BC | 15 September 250 BC | 2 days | |- | Sultan [[Khalid bin Barghash of Zanzibar|Sayyid Khalid bin Barghash]] | [[Zanzibar]] | [[List of Sultans of Zanzibar|Al Bu Sa'id]] | 25 August 1896 | 27 August 1896 | 2 days | Seized power after the death of [[Hamad bin Thuwaini of Zanzibar|Sayyid Hamad bin Thuwaini Al-Busaid]] resulting in the 38 minute [[Anglo-Zanzibar War]]. Replaced by [[Hamoud bin Mohammed of Zanzibar|Sayyid Hamoud bin Mohammed Al-Said]] after surrender. |} ==Less than a day== ''Due to the ephemeral nature of their reigns, the following have been disputed as genuine monarchs:'' {| class="wikitable" ! width="16%" | Name ! width="10%" | Country ! width="12%" | Royal house/dynasty ! width="12%" | Reign began ! width="12%" | Reign ended ! width="10%" | Length ! width="28%" | Comments |- | Emperor [[Michael of Trebizond|Michael I Megas Komnenos]] | [[Empire of Trebizond]] | [[Komnenos]] | 30 July 1341 | 31 July 1341 | Less than 24 hours | First reign : as the legitimate male descendant of the ruling family, Michael received the support of much of the populace and was acclaimed emperor. Some of the nobility, led by the Metropolitan Akakios received him as their lord and escorted him into the palace. As soon as night fell, however, the nobles imprisoned Michael, not wishing to be ruled by a mature and forceful monarch. |- | Tsar [[Grand Duke Michael Alexandrovich of Russia|Michael II]] | [[Russian Empire]] | [[Romanov]] | 15 March 1917 | 16 March 1917 | 16 hours | Deferred acceptance. Later killed. |- | [[Emperor Mo of Jin|Emperor Mo]] | [[China]] | [[Jin dynasty (1115–1234)|Jin]] | 9 February 1234 | 9 February 1234 | 12 hours | Crowned while under assault by Mongolians at the [[Siege of Caizhou]] and killed after the coronation. |- | [[Victoria Kamāmalu]] | [[Kingdom of Hawaii|Hawaii]] | [[House of Kamehameha|Kamehameha]] | 30 November 1864 | 30 November 1864 | 5 hours and 45 minutes | As [[Kuhina Nui]], she effectively became head of state upon her brother Kamehameha IV's death at 9:15 a.m. until her other brother [[Kamehameha V]]'s declaration as the actual successor at 3 p.m. the same day.{{cite book|last1=Dutton|first1=Meiric Keeler|last2=Harris|first2=Charles Coffin|authorlink2=Charles Coffin Harris|title=The Succession of King Kamehameha V to Hawaii's Throne: Including a Recently-Discovered Private Memorandum Written by Attorney-General C. C. Harris|year=1957|publisher=Loomis House Press|location=Honolulu|page=11}} |- | [[Daughter of Emperor Xiaoming of Northern Wei]] | [[China]] | [[Northern Wei]] | 1 April 528 | 1 April 528 | Less than 5 hours | Soon after her birth, her grandmother, the [[Empress Dowager Hu (Northern Wei)|Empress Dowager Hu]], falsely declared she was a boy and ordered a [[amnesty|general pardon]]. [[Emperor Xiaoming of Northern Wei|Emperor Xiaoming]] died soon afterwards. On 1 April 528, Empress Dowager Hu installed the infant on the throne for a matter of hours before replacing her with [[Yuan Zhao]] the next day.{{cite web|url=http://cul.shangdu.com/yeshi/20130716/315_5820728_1.shtml |script-title=zh:历史上短命的皇帝有哪些 |trans-title=Short-lived emperors in history |publisher=Henan Culture Web (河南文化网) |date=2013-07-16 |accessdate=2013-11-17 |website=Shangdu.com |language=zh |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202233733/http://cul.shangdu.com/yeshi/20130716/315_5820728_1.shtml |archivedate=2 December 2013 |df= }} |} ==Less than an hour== ''Due to the ephemeral nature of his reign, the following has been disputed as a genuine monarch:'' {| class="wikitable" ! width="16%" | Name ! width="10%" | Country ! width="12%" | Royal house/dynasty ! width="12%" | Reign began ! width="12%" | Reign ended ! width="10%" | Length ! width="28%" | Comments |- | Prince [[Louis Antoine, Duke of Angoulême]], "King Louis XIX" | [[Kingdom of France]] | [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon]] | 2 August 1830 | 2 August 1830 | 20 minutes | Succeeded with the abdication of his father, [[Charles X of France|Charles X]], only to himself abdicate in favour of his nephew, [[Henri, Count of Chambord|Henry V]] (above). The question of whether Louis actually "reigned" is a philosophical one, as after his father signed the document of abdication, he contemplated his future for twenty minutes before himself signing. Many [[Legitimists]] did not recognise the abdications as valid, and recognised Charles X as king until his death in 1836, before recognising Louis as king until his own death in 1844. |- |} ==See also== * [[Pope#Shortest-reigning popes|List of shortest-reigning popes]] * [[Current reigning monarchs by length of reign]] * [[List of longest-reigning monarchs]] * [[List of the oldest living state leaders]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Shortest Reigning Monarchs Of All Time}} [[Category:Lists of monarchs by length of reign| Shortest]] [[Category:History-related lists of superlatives|Shortest reigning monarchs of all time]]

page.title: List of years in British television

revision.text:
<!-- Please DO NOT ADD anything to this list until AFTER it has been added to the relevant year in television itself. SGBailey --> This page indexes the individual '''year in [[British television]]''' pages. Each year is annotated with a significant event as a reference point. {{horizontal TOC|nonum=yes}}
==2010s== * '''[[2019 in British television]]''' – * '''[[2018 in British television]]''' – BBC One airs the first of two editions of the latest version of ''[[The Generation Game]]'', which is presented by Mel and Sue along with airing The Queen's Birthday Party, a concert from London's Royal Albert Hall celebrating the 92nd birthday of [[Queen Elizabeth II]]. Spring 2018 also sees [[The National Lottery Draws|The National Lottery results]] being broadcast on ITV for the first time after more than two decades on the BBC, with the results appearing as a 90-second summary as part of an advert break. September 2018 sees ''[[The Circle (TV series)|The Circle]]'' debut on Channel 4. * '''[[2017 in British television]]''' – The Saturday evening [[The National Lottery Draws|National Lottery Draw]] stops being shown on [[BBC One]] and is now only seen on the [[BBC iPlayer]], the Corporation having taken the decision to stop broadcasting the draw live on BBC One after agreeing a news,<ref>{{url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-38102851 |title=The National Lottery draw will no longer be on BBC One |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=25 November 2016 |accessdate=25 december 2016}}</ref> [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]], the ''[[Teletubbies]]'' and ''[[Robot Wars (TV series)|Robot Wars]]'' all celebrate their 20th anniversaries, ''[[In the Night Garden]]'', ''[[Shaun the Sheep]]'' and ''[[Golden Balls]]'' all celebrate their 10th anniversaries. ITV launches its pay-per-view service [[ITV Box Office]], Wimbledon Tennis celebrates 90 years on the BBC during Wimbledon Tennis' 140th anniversary and [[Channel 4]], [[S4C]] and ''[[Countdown (game show)|Countdown]]'' all celebrate their 35th anniversaries. * '''[[2016 in British television]]''' – The BBC announces a deal with [[Discovery Communications]] that enables it to broadcast coverage of the Summer and Winter Olympics up to and including the [[2024 Summer Olympic Games]]. The agreement covers television, radio and online coverage, [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]], [[5Star|5*]] and [[5 USA|5USA]] get a new look on 11 February as their stencil logos for their channels get their very first airing. 5* is also rebranded as 5Star on the same day. ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]'' celebrates its 30th anniversary with a special feature-length episode. * '''[[2015 in British television]]''' – 10th anniversary of the [[Doctor Who (series 1)|2005 relaunch]] of ''[[Doctor Who]]'', The rebooted series of ''[[Teletubbies]]'' will feature voiceovers from names including [[Jane Horrocks]], [[Jim Broadbent]] and [[Fearne Cotton]], it is revealed, EastEnders concludes the Who Killed Lucy Beale? storyline by revealing her younger brother Bobby Beale as her killer live in a special flashback episode to celebrate the show's 30th anniversary, ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' celebrates its 50th anniversary with the debut of animated reboot ''[[Thunderbirds Are Go (TV series)|Thunderbirds Are Go ]]'', [[Brian Blessed]] and [[Dave Lamb]]. The [[CBBC (TV channel)|CBBC channel]] will also air a 60-minute programme celebrating thirty years of ''The Broom Cupboard'', the studio from which [[CBBC]] [[continuity (broadcasting)|continuity presenters]] [[Andi Peters]], [[Philip Schofield]], [[Zoë Ball]] and [[Edd the Duck]], [[Louisa Johnson]] becomes the youngest ever contestant to win ''[[The X Factor]]'' and launch of YourTV on Freeview and YouView, Fox UK's first free-to-air channel and which is targeted at women. * '''[[2014 in British television]]''' – 50th anniversary of the first edition of ''[[Top of the Pops]]''. Although an edition was aired on New Year's Eve 2013, the anniversary itself goes unmarked by the BBC because of the programme's association with the late [[Jimmy Savile]]. The first episode of [[Channel 4]]'s controversial documentary series ''[[Benefits Street]]'' attracts several hundred viewer complaints. [[BBC Two]] celebrates its 50th anniversary along with ''[[Match of the Day]]''. * '''[[2013 in British television]]''' – [[BBC Two]] launches in [[High-definition television|high-definition]] for the first time 2 and a half years after [[BBC One]] did, ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' becomes the first ongoing British TV progaramme to reach and celebrate its 60th anniversary since ''BBC Wimbledon'' and ''BBC Cricket'', [[More4]] also launches in HD for the first time, [[CITV]] will celebrate its 30th anniversary by airing an ''Old Skool'' weekend and ''[[Doctor Who]]'' celebrates its 50th anniversary by airing a [[The Day of the Doctor|special episode]] all across both Britain and the globe. Spring 2013 also sees the BBC Television centre's old building close with all the BBC services in London moving to the new one next door known as the [[Broadcasting House]] along with the debut of ''[[Gogglebox]]'' and ''[[Peaky Blinders (TV series)|Peaky Blinders]]'' on [[Channel 4]] and [[BBC Two]]. * '''[[2012 in British television]]''' – Spring of this year sees ''[[The Weakest Link (UK game show)|The Weakest Link]]'' come to an end with the 1,693rd edition, when [[Anne Robinson]] retires from the show to concentrate on Brand newer series of ''[[Watchdog (TV series)|Watchdog]]'', [[CBeebies]] celebrates 10 years of being separated from [[CBBC]], Spring 2012 also sees ''[[Harry Hill's TV Burp]]'' ending on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] with a huge finale after 10 or 11 years of broadcast, as well as the ''[[Teletubbies]]'' celebrating their 15th actual anniversary on the [[BBC]]. The events of the [[2012 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]] begin airing with the opening ceremony in [[London]] as well as the debut of ''[[Tipping Point (game show)|Tipping Point]]'' from July of this year. The [[Digital terrestrial television in the United Kingdom#Digital switchover|Digital Switchover]] is completed in October as the final analogue transmitters are switched off in [[Northern Ireland]]. * '''[[2011 in British television]]''' – Viewers watch the [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton]], and the first broadcast of ''[[Mrs. Brown's Boys]]'' on [[BBC One]]. [[Little Mix]] become the first group to win ''[[The X Factor]]''. * '''[[2010 in British television]]''' – ''[[Coronation Street]]'' celebrates its 50th year on air with a [[Coronation Street: 50th anniversary live episode|live episode]], while ''[[EastEnders]]'' marks its 25th anniversary.
==2000s==
* '''[[2009 in British television]]''' – This year sees many changes at [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] as the company encounters financial troubles and The ''[[Coach Trip]]'' returns after 3 years of absence along with ''[[The Biggest Loser (UK TV series)|The Biggest Loser]]''. 2009 also sees [[Six TV]] in Oxfordshire and Southampton defunct after only 10 years of localized airing and ''[[Horrible Histories (2009 TV series)|Horrible Histories]]'' begins on [[CBBC]], ''[[Timmy Time]]'' begins on [[CBeebies]] and ''[[Divided (game show)|Divided]]'', ''[[The Chase (UK game show)|The Chase]]'' and ''[[The Cube (game show)|The Cube]]'' all begin on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV1]] as well. * '''[[2008 in British television]]''' – Weekly comparison between overweight and underweight people programme ''[[Supersize vs Superskinny]]'' appears, [[Freesat]] officially launches while [[ITV HD]] launches a full service and ITV's ''[[ITV News at Ten|News at Ten]]'' returns for its third run after being axed again four years previously. ''[[The Inbetweeners]]'' also debuts on [[E4 (TV channel)|E4]] along with the ''[[Big Brother (UK)|Big Brother]]'' zombie miniseries ''[[Dead Set]]''. * '''[[2007 in British television]]''' – A series of [[2007 television phone-in scandals|scandals]] involving allegations of phone-in segments of television programmes and quiz channels conning viewers, The [[BBC]] launches [[BBC iPlayer]], The town of [[Whitehaven]] in [[Cumbria]] becomes the first place in the UK to lose their [[analog television|analogue television]] signals and start the [[digital switchover]] and [[ITV Play]] is defunct and rebranded as ITV Bingo. 2007 also sees the debuts of ''[[Golden Balls]]'', ''[[Benidorm (TV series)|Benidorm]]'' and ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'' on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV1]] along with the [[CBBC]] Halloween-themed game show ''[[Trapped! (TV series)|Trapped!]]'', ''[[Shaun the Sheep]]'' and the ''[[Prank Patrol (UK TV series)|Prank Patrol]]'' on [[CBBC]], ''[[In the Night Garden]]'' on [[CBeebies]] and ''[[Gavin & Stacey]]'' and ''[[Outnumbered (British TV series)|Outnumbered]]'' on [[BBC One]]. * '''[[2006 in British television]]''' – [[ITV Play]] and the [[CITV]] Channel both launch, [[Michael Grade]] is appointed as chief executive of [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], [[Richard Hammond]] is seriously injured while driving a jet-powered car for a piece for ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]'', ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' axe weekly episodes before revival by Christmas and ''[[Stars in Their Eyes]]'' is also axed along with ''[[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|They Think It's All Over]]'' due to viewer shortages. 2006 also sees ''[[The Slammer]]'' begin on [[CBBC]] as well as ''[[Dancing on Ice]]'' on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. * '''[[2005 in British television]]''' – After an absence of 16 years ''[[Doctor Who]]'' returns to British television starting with [[Christopher Eccleston]] in the leading role, The quiz show ''[[Deal or No Deal (UK game show)|Deal or No Deal]]'' is launched along with the ''[[Coach Trip]]'' and ''[[The Biggest Loser (UK TV series)|The Biggest Loser]]'', ''[[The Two Ronnies Sketchbook]]'' sequels to take over from ''[[The Two Ronnies]]'', [[More4]] is launched and the [[ITV News Channel]] is defunct. 2005 also sees the debut of ''[[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' on [[BBC One]]. * '''[[2004 in British television]]''' – ''[[Supernanny]]'' launches a year before the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|London Bombings]], ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'' sequels to take over from ''[[Come Dancing]]'', [[Greg Dyke]] resigns as [[Director-General of the BBC]] in the wake of the [[Hutton Report]] and ''[[ITV News at Ten|News at Ten]]'' axes from ITV for a second time. ''[[Peppa Pig]]'' also debuts on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]], along with ''[[Something Special (TV series)|Something Special]]'' on [[CBeebies]] and the long-running [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] singing talent show ''[[The X Factor]]''. 2004 also sees [[Tiny Pop]] launched in the UK. * '''[[2003 in British television]]''' – ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' becomes the first British television programme to reach its 50th anniversary since ''BBC Wimbledon'' and ''BBC Cricket'' and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] screens the controversial [[Martin Bashir]] documentary ''[[Living with Michael Jackson]]'' * '''[[2002 in British television]]''' – [[Will Young]] is voted winner of the first series of ''[[Pop Idol]]'', ''[[Harry Hill's TV Burp]]'' begins on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV1]] with [[ITV2]] showing repeats afterwards, along with ''[[I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here]]'' and ''[[Ant and Dec's Saturday Night Takeaway]]'', [[CBeebies]] launches to separate from [[CBBC]], [[ITV Digital]] is replaced by [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]], the [[ITV Sport Channel]] is defunct and Channel 5 is rebranded as [[Channel 5 (UK)|Five]]. 2002 also sees ''[[Raven (BBC TV series)|Raven]]'', ''[[The Story of Tracy Beaker]]'', ''[[The Basil Brush Show]]'' and ''[[Dick and Dom in Da Bungalow]]'' begin on [[CBBC]] along with ''[[BrainTeaser]]'' appearing on Channel 5. * '''[[2001 in British television]]''' – The world witnesses the [[September 11 terrorist attacks]] on [[New York City]] and [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]]. Regular programming is suspended in order to bring up to date coverage of events relating to the attacks. [[Charles Ingram]] cheats to win the £1 million prize on ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire]]''. ITV's ''[[ITV News at Ten|News at Ten]]'' returns after being axed two years previously, the [[ITV Sport Channel]] launches along with [[E4 (TV channel)|E4]] and [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] rebrands its English and Welsh services to ITV1. 2001 also sees TV soap ''[[Crossroads (soap opera)|Crossroads]]'' return after 13 years of absence and ''[[The Office (UK TV series)|The Office]]'' debut on [[BBC Two]]. * '''[[2000 in British television]]''' – [[Judith Keppel]] becomes the first contestant to win the £1 million prize on ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire]]''. The UK versions of ''[[The Weakest Link (UK game show)|The Weakest Link]]'' and ''[[Big Brother (UK)|Big Brother]]'' also debut this year. ''[[Coronation Street]]'' celebrates 40 years on air with a [[Coronation Street: 40th anniversary live episode|live episode]] and the [[ITV News Channel]] launches.
==1990s==
* '''[[1999 in British television]]''' – Popular television presenter [[Jill Dando]] is assassinated outside her home in West London, The murder remains unsolved to the present day, [[Six TV]], Britain's sixth and last terrestrial localised channel launches in both [[Oxfordshire]] and [[Southampton]], [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] axes ''[[ITV News at Ten|News at Ten]]'' after a run of 32 years and [[BBC One]] broadcasts a marathon [[2000 Today|28-hour programme]] to welcome in the new millennium. 1999 also sees the debut of ''[[Tweenies]]'' on [[BBC One]]. * '''[[1998 in British television]]''' – Digital [[satellite television]] is launched in the UK, spearheaded by [[Sky (UK & Ireland)|Sky]]. The UK's first two digital only stations, [[BBC Choice]] and [[ITV2]] are both launched. [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] launches ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? (UK game show)|Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'', ''[[Bob The Builder]]'' appears on [[BBC One]], [[Sky Sports News]] is also launched and ''[[Come Dancing]]'' the last of the ongoing 1940s debuts leaves the BBC after nearly 50 years. 1998 also sees ''[[Don't Try This at Home (TV series)|Don't Try This at Home]]'' take over from ''[[You Bet!]]'' at [[Shepperton Studios]]. * '''[[1997 in British television]]''' – Launch of [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]], Britain's fifth terrestrial channel followed by the first appearance of the ''[[Teletubbies]]'' on [[BBC Two]], The [[UKTV]] network and [[BBC News 24]] are also launched. Programming schedules are abandoned to provide up to date news coverage following the [[death of Diana, Princess of Wales]]. 1997 also sees the futuristic game show ''[[Robot Wars (TV series)|Robot Wars]]'' filmed in the latter half of this year and then appears on [[BBC Two]] in the early half of the following year. * '''[[1996 in British television]]''' – Launch of [[Granada Sky Broadcasting]] and an unsuccessful rebranding of the [[ITV Tyne Tees]] region. 1996 also sees the beginning of a new Friday entertainment show towards the new millennium ''[[TFI Friday]]'' on [[Channel 4]]. * '''[[1995 in British television]]''' – This year sees the launch of several new satellite TV channels, as well as the first [[National Television Awards]]. ''[[Father Ted]]'' also debuts on [[Channel 4]]. 1995 also sees the beginning of the sport game show ''[[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|They Think It's All Over]]''. * '''[[1994 in British television]]''' – The [[1988–94 British broadcasting voice restrictions|1988–1994 broadcasting ban]] is lifted when the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army|Provisional IRA]] declares a ceasefire. After an absence of 7 years ''[[University Challenge]]'' returns along with ''[[Play Your Cards Right]]'', [[BBC One]] airs the first [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]] draw and [[BBC Two]] celebrates its 30th birthday. 1994 also sees ''[[Wipeout (UK game show)|Wipeout]]'' appear along with ''[[Small Talk (UK game show)|Small Talk]]''. * '''[[1993 in British television]]''' – [[Carlton Television]] takes over the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] London Weekday franchise, replacing [[Thames Television]] after 24 years. Additionally, [[Meridian Broadcasting]] takes over the South of England franchise from [[Television South|TVS]], [[Westcountry Television]] takes over the South West England franchise from [[Television South West|TSW]], and [[GMTV]] takes over the [[breakfast television]] franchise from [[TV-am]]. 1993 also sees [[Teletext Ltd]] take over the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] and [[Channel 4]] teletext franchises from [[ORACLE (teletext)|ORACLE]]. * '''[[1992 in British television]]''' – The controversial one-off drama ''[[Ghostwatch]]'' is broadcast on [[BBC One]], a 'live' investigation into a haunted North London house. [[UKTV Gold|UK Gold]] is launched, a joint venture between the [[BBC]] and [[Thames Television]]. 1992 also sees ''[[University Challenge]]'', ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'', ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]'' and ''[[Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons]]'' all move from [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] to the [[BBC]]. Live coverage of top flight English football transferred from ITV to [[Sky Sports]] meaning that viewers had to pay a subscription fee to watch the newly formed [[Premier League]]. * '''[[1991 in British television]]''' – Regular programming is abandoned in order to bring live coverage of the [[Gulf War]] after Allied Forces launch [[Gulf War#Air campaign|Operation Desert Storm]] against [[Iraq]]. Over the duration of the war there is extended coverage of events in the Persian Gulf. ITV also broadcasts news and discussion programmes about the war throughout the night. Some broadcasting, particularly in the earlier part of the war, comes from [[CNN]]. Also this year the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] [[ITV Network#The Fifth Franchise Round: 1993|franchise auction]] results are announced and take effect starting midnight [[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]] on 1 January 1993. * '''[[1990 in British television]]''' – [[British Satellite Broadcasting]] (BSB) is launched, but later merges with [[Sky Television plc]] after an unsuccessful run, The [[Broadcasting Act 1990|Broadcasting Bill]] receives Royal Assent, pop music game show ''[[Stars in Their Eyes]]'' first appears on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] along with ''[[You've Been Framed!]]'' and ''[[Mr. Bean]]'', popular [[BBC]] sitcom ''[[One Foot in the Grave]]'' also appears and ''[[The Simpsons]]'' debut on Sky.
==1980s==
* '''[[1989 in British television]]''' – [[Sky Television plc]] is launched while the government introduces a controversial [[Broadcasting Act 1990|Broadcasting Bill]] that will pave the way for the deregulation of commercial television. Also ''[[A Grand Day Out]]'' starring [[Wallace and Gromit]] debuts first on [[Channel 4]] before moving to the BBC ''and [[Red Dwarf]]'' debuts on [[BBC Two|BBC2]]. * '''[[1988 in British television]]''' – [[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]] airs its first [[Red Nose Day]] fundraiser on [[BBC One]] while [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] broadcasts ''[[Death on the Rock]]'', a hugely controversial episode of [[Thames Television]]'s ''[[This Week (ITV TV series)|This Week]]'' current affairs strand, investigating [[Operation Flavius]], which resulted in the [[Special Air Service|SAS]] killing three members of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army|IRA]] in [[Gibraltar]]. The British government introduces [[1988–94 British broadcasting voice restrictions|6 years of regulations]] banning the direct broadcast of people representing eleven [[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]] and [[Ulster loyalism|Ulster loyalist]] groups. ''[[You Bet!]]'' appears along with ''[[This Morning (TV programme)|This Morning]]'' and ''[[Fifteen to One|15 to 1]]''. 1988 also sees the end of the long-running soap ''[[Crossroads (soap opera)|Crossroads]]'' along with ''[[Play School (UK TV series)|Play School]]'' to be replaced by ''[[Playdays]]''. * '''[[1987 in British television]]''' – ''[[Going for Gold]]'', ''[[Fireman Sam]]'' and ''[[Charlie Chalk]]'' all debut on [[BBC One]], The [[TV-am]] strike begins after members of the technician’s union the [[ACTT]] walk out in a dispute over the station's ‘Caring Christmas Campaign.’ What is meant to be a 24-hour stoppage continues for several months when staff are locked out by Managing Director [[Bruce Gyngell]]. ITV is unable to broadcast ''[[Good Morning Britain (1983)|Good Morning Britain]]'', the regular format is replaced with a skeleton service that sees non-technical staff operating cameras and Gyngell himself directing proceedings, as well as imported shows such as ''[[Flipper (1964 TV series)|Flipper]]'', ''[[Batman]]'' and ''[[Happy Days]]'' being used to fill up the station's airtime. The strikers are eventually sacked and replaced with non union staff. Viewing figures remain high throughout the disruption, which continues well into 1988, although normal programming gradually resumes. Other ITV stations later follow Gyngell's example. 1987 also sees the [[ITV Schools]] service move to [[Channel 4]] to allow ITV to develop a fully commercial daytime schedule and ''[[The Old Grey Whistle Test]]'' and ''[[The Two Ronnies]]'' end as does the original run of ''[[University Challenge]]''. * '''[[1986 in British television]]''' – [[BBC One]] begins a full daytime schedule service for the first time, while [[Yorkshire Television|Yorkshire]] becomes the first [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] region to begin broadcasting 24 hours a day. 1986 also sees ''[[Neighbours]]'' make its British television debut along with ''[[Pingu]]'', ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]'' and ''[[Catchphrase (UK game show)|Catchphrase]]''. * '''[[1985 in British television]]''' – ''[[EastEnders]]'' debuts along with ''[[Howards' Way]]'', ''[[Bertha (TV series)|Bertha]]'' and ''[[Telly Addicts]]'' on [[BBC One]], The 17-hour [[Live Aid]] concert takes place in both London and [[Philadelphia]], The last [[405-line]] [[transmitter]]s are switched off in the UK and [[CBBC|Children's BBC]] is also launched. * '''[[1984 in British television]]''' – [[Thames Television]] goes off the air for one day when technical staff walk out on strike, [[BBC One]] airs the first edition of ''[[Crimewatch]]'' and ''[[Thomas the Tank Engine and Friends]]'' debuts on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] 22 years before moving to its soon to launch channel [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]]. * '''[[1983 in British television]]''' – [[BBC One]] and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] launch their respective [[breakfast television]] services. [[CITV|Children's ITV]] is also launched. 1983 also sees [[Bob Holness]] presenting the first edition of ''[[Blockbusters (UK game show)|Blockbusters]]'' on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]]. * '''[[1982 in British television]]''' – [[Channel 4]], Britain's fourth terrestrial channel, goes on air, along with the first airing of its first and long running teatime game show ''[[Countdown (game show)|Countdown]]'' and first animated Christmas special ''[[The Snowman]]''; [[S4C]], a Welsh-language version is also launched. "The Satellite Channel", the channel which later became [[Sky One]], also goes on air. * '''[[1981 in British television]]''' – Viewers watch the [[Wedding of Charles, Prince of Wales and Lady Diana Spencer]], ''[[Only Fools and Horses]]'' and ''[[Postman Pat]]'' both debut on [[BBC One]]. ''[[Danger Mouse (1981 TV series)|Danger Mouse]]'' debuts on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. [[Associated TeleVision|ATV]], [[Southern Television|Southern]], and [[Westward Television|Westward]] go off air after losing their broadcasting franchises – they are replaced on 1 January 1982 by [[Central Independent Television|Central]], [[Television South|TVS]] and [[Television South West|TSW]] respectively. * '''[[1980 in British television]]''' – Launch of ''[[Newsnight]]'', the first televising of ''[[Watchdog (TV series)|Watchdog]]'', ''[[Family Fortunes]]'' and ''[[Play Your Cards Right]]'' both debut on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] and the first ''BBC [[Children in Need]]'' telethon.
==1970s==
* '''[[1979 in British television]]''' – Technicians at [[Thames Television]] go on strike – the dispute quickly spreads to other regions in the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] network and ITV is off air for eleven weeks from 10 August to 24 October, [[Ceefax]] begins [[Closed captioning|subtitles]] for some programmes, [[Robin Day]] presents the first edition of ''[[Question Time (TV series)|Question Time]]'' and [[Terry Wogan]] presents the first edition of ''[[Blankety Blank]]''. * '''[[1978 in British television]]''' – [[Anna Ford]] becomes the first female news reader on [[Independent Television News|ITN]] and the first of [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s ''[[An Audience with]]'' is aired, presented by [[Jasper Carrott]]. * '''[[1977 in British television]]''' – Colour television licenses exceed black & white licenses and repeated black & white programmes for the first time in the UK since ITV's colour strike and ''[[Jesus of Nazareth (miniseries)|Jesus of Nazareth]]'', an [[United Kingdom|Anglo]]-[[Italy|Italian]] [[television]] [[miniseries]] dramatizing the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth]], life, [[Ministry of Jesus|ministry]], [[Crucifixion of Jesus|death]], and [[Resurrection of Jesus|resurrection]] of [[Jesus]] based on the accounts in the four [[New Testament]] [[Gospel]]s debuts on British television. The series stars [[Robert Powell]] as Jesus. * '''[[1976 in British television]]''' – The ''[[Multicoloured Swap Shop]]'' opens on the [[BBC]], Punk group the [[Sex Pistols]] cause a storm of controversy and outrage in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] by swearing well before the [[watershed (television)|watershed]] on the regional [[Thames Television]] news programme ''Today'', hosted by [[Bill Grundy]] but Grundy, who has goaded them into doing so, is temporarily sacked making the news programme ''Today'' come to an end. * '''[[1975 in British television]]''' – The popular sitcom ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'' first appears along with ''[[The Good Life (1975 TV series)|The Good Life]]'', ''[[Space 1999]]'' and ''[[Paddington (1975 TV series)|Paddington Bear]]'' on British television screens, as well as the police drama ''[[The Sweeney]]''. 1975 also sees the first transmission of a [[James Bond]] film on British television. * '''[[1974 in British television]]''' – The [[BBC]] teletext service [[Ceefax]] first goes on air with 30 pages of information, and the Saturday morning children's entertainment series ''[[Tiswas]]'' is launched by [[Associated TeleVision|ATV]]. * '''[[1973 in British television]]''' – Debuts of [[Thames Television]]'s critically acclaimed documentary series ''[[The World at War]]'', and ''[[The Wombles (1973 TV series)|The Wombles]]'' on [[BBC Two]]. * '''[[1972 in British television]]''' – First Community Cable Television Experiment awarded to [[Greenwich Cablevision]]. – Debut of [[BBC One]]'s ''[[Newsround]]'' and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s ''[[Emmerdale|Emmerdale Farm]]'', both of which continue to air to the present day, and ''[[Rainbow (TV series)|Rainbow]]''. * '''[[1971 in British television]]''' – End of ITV's colour strike, Launch of the ''[[Old Grey Whistle Test]]'', popular comedy show ''[[The Two Ronnies]]'' and the popular series ''[[Upstairs, Downstairs (1971 TV series)|Upstairs, Downstairs]]''. * '''[[1970 in British television]]''' – The ''[[BBC Nine O'Clock News]]'' goes on air for the first time and staff at [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] begin a [[Colour Strike|three-month colour strike]], making colour television programmes black & white like in previous years, after a dispute with their management over pay from 13 November of this year to February and December of the following year. ''[[The Goodies]]'' also debuts on [[BBC Two]], as well as ''[[The Adventures of Rupert Bear]]''.
==1960s==
* '''[[1969 in British television]]''' – Regular [[colour television]] broadcasting begins on [[BBC One]] and [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]], and the world watches footage of the [[1969 moon landing]]. * '''[[1968 in British television]]''' – Following franchise changes technical staff at [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] stage a strike, leading to ITV management establishing an [[ITV Emergency National Service|emergency national service]] for the duration of the industrial action and popular BBC sitcom ''[[Dad's Army]]'' begins along with ''[[Joe 90]]''. * '''[[1967 in British television]]''' – [[BBC Two]] begins colour broadcasting at the [[Wimbledon Championships]] and [[Patrick McGoohan]]'s cult television series ''[[The Prisoner]]'' debuts on ITV, along with ''[[Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons]]'' and ''[[ITV News at Ten|News at Ten]]'' is also launched on ITV. * '''[[1966 in British television]]''' – ''[[Cathy Come Home]]'', possibly the best-known play ever to be broadcast on British television, is presented in [[BBC One]]'s ''[[The Wednesday Play]]'' anthology strand. * '''[[1965 in British television]]''' – [[Cigarette]] advertising is banned on British television and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s Saturday afternoon ''[[World of Sport (UK TV series)|World of Sport]]'' programme and popular [[Supermarionation]], ''[[Thunderbirds (TV series)|Thunderbirds]]'' both begin airing. * '''[[1964 in British television]]''' – [[BBC Two]] goes on the air and long-running football and music shows ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' and ''[[Match of the Day]]'' are both launched and ''[[Stingray (1964 TV series)|Stingray]]'' begins on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]]. * '''[[1963 in British television]]''' – The science fiction series ''[[Doctor Who]]'' is aired for the first time and the satirical show ''[[That Was The Week That Was]]'' comes to an end after series 2. * '''[[1962 in British television]]''' – [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] finally arrives in North West Wales and the Channel Islands with the launch of [[Wales West and North Television]] and [[Channel Television]] and the satirical show ''[[That Was The Week That Was]]'' begins with only two series. * '''[[1961 in British television]]''' – [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]]'s [[Westward Television|Westward]], [[Border Television|Border]] and [[Grampian Television|Grampian]] regions are established. ''[[The Avengers (TV series)|The Avengers]]'' and ''[[Points of View (TV series)|Points of View]]'' debut on British television. * '''[[1960 in British television]]''' – The [[Pilkington Committee on Broadcasting]] is established to look at the future of broadcasting and paves the way for the establishment of soon to launch channel [[BBC Two]]. ''[[Coronation Street]]'', Britain's longest-running television soap, debuts on [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]]. [[Nan Winton]] becomes the first national female newsreader on BBC television.
==1950s==
*'''[[1959 in British television]]''' – [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]]'s [[Anglia Television|Anglia]], [[Tyne Tees Television|Tyne Tees]] and [[Ulster Television|Ulster]] regions go on air. *'''[[1958 in British television]]''' – ITV's [[Television Wales and the West|TWW]] and [[Southern Television|Southern]] regions go on air and ''[[Blue Peter]]'', the world's longest-running children's programme, is first broadcast by the [[BBC]] along with long-running various sport show ''[[Grandstand (TV series)|Grandstand]]''. *'''[[1957 in British television]]''' – ''[[The Sky at Night]]'', the longest-running television programme hosted by the same presenter, [[Patrick Moore]], begins on the [[BBC]]. ITV's [[Scottish Television|Scottish]] region goes on air. *'''[[1956 in British television]]''' – ''[[Hancock's Half Hour]]'', regarded as the first modern [[situation comedy|sitcom]] which began on [[BBC Radio]], is transferred to [[BBC]] television. ITV's [[Granada Television|Granada]] and [[Associated TeleVision|ATV]] regions go on air during weekdays. The weekend franchise in both areas is operated by [[Associated British Corporation|ABC]]. *'''[[1955 in British television]]''' – [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] launches, resulting in the destruction of the [[BBC]]'s 23-year-long [[monopoly]] on British television. *'''[[1954 in British television]]''' – ''[[The Grove Family]]'', regarded as Britain's first soap, begins airing. *'''[[1953 in British television]]''' – The [[Coronation of the British monarch|coronation]] of [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom]] sees a vast increase in television set sales. *'''[[1952 in British television]]''' – The funeral of King [[George VI of the United Kingdom|George VI]] is televised in the [[United Kingdom|UK]]. *'''[[1951 in British television]]''' – The [[Holme Moss]] transmitter is opened in [[Northern England]], making [[BBC One|BBC Television]] available to the region for the first time. *'''[[1950 in British television]]''' – First televised report of general election results in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].
==1940s==
*'''[[1949 in British television]]''' – The [[Sutton Coldfield television transmitter]] is opened in the [[English Midlands|Midlands]], making it the first part of the [[United Kingdom|UK]] outside [[London]] to receive [[BBC One|BBC Television]] and long-running dancing show ''[[Come Dancing]]'' launches. *'''[[1948 in British television]]''' – The [[BBC One|BBC Television Service]] resumes broadcasting again and begins its coverage of the [[1948 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]] in [[London]]. *'''[[1947 in British television]]''' – The [[BBC One|BBC Television Service]] broadcasts are temporarily suspended since [[World War II]] due to a national fuel crisis. *'''[[1946 in British television]]''' – The [[BBC]] resumes broadcasting for the first time since the end of [[World War II]]. *'''[[1945 in British television]]''' – No television is broadcast during World War II. [[World War II]] ends on 2 September. *'''[[1944 in British television]]''' – No television is broadcast during World War II. *'''[[1943 in British television]]''' – No television is broadcast during World War II. *'''[[1942 in British television]]''' – No television is broadcast during World War II. *'''[[1941 in British television]]''' – No television is broadcast during World War II. *'''[[1940 in British television]]''' – No television is broadcast during World War II.
==1930s==
*'''[[1939 in British television]]''' – Television broadcasts are suspended during World War II for fear that the signals would help German bombers. *'''[[1938 in British television]]''' – First news bulletin carried by BBC television, in sound only. Previously, the service had aired British Movietone News cinema newsreels. *'''[[1937 in British television]]''' – First outside broadcast at the Coronation of [[King George VI of the United Kingdom|King George VI]]. *'''[[1936 in British television]]''' – Electronically scanned television begins from [[Alexandra Palace]]. *'''[[1935 in British television]]''' – Baird stops broadcasting in September. *'''[[1934 in British television]]''' – The agreement for joint experimental transmissions by the BBC and John Logie Baird's company comes to an end. *'''[[1933 in British television]]''' – The first television revue, Looking In, is shown on the BBC *'''[[1932 in British television]]''' – [[BBC Television]] begins broadcasting a regular channel, which later becomes [[BBC One]]. *'''[[1931 in British television]]''' – No events for this year. *'''[[1930 in British television]]''' – John Logie Baird installs a television receiver at the British Prime Minister's residence in London.
==1920s==
*'''[[1929 in British television]]''' – [[John Logie Baird]] begins broadcasting 30-minute-long programmes for his mechanically scanned televisions. *'''[[1928 in British television]]''' – John Logie Baird's Television Development Company demonstrates their model A, B, and C 'televisors' to the general public. *'''[[1927 in British television]]''' – The BBC begins broadcasting as the British Broadcasting Corporation under the [[Royal Charter]]. *'''[[1926 in British television]]''' – [[John Logie Baird]] demonstrates the world's first television system.

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = Loving Pablo, Hating Escobar | title_orig = Amando a Pablo, odiando a Escobar | translator = | image = File:Loving Pablo, Hating Escobar.jpg | caption = Original Spanish version | author = [[Virginia Vallejo]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | genre = Autobiography, biography | release_date = 2007 | english_pub_date = 2018 | publisher = [[Canongate Books|Canongate]] (UK)
[[Doubleday (publisher)|Knopf Doubleday]] (US) | pages = {{ubl | 384 (UK Edition) | 416 (US Edition)}} | ISBN = 978-1-78689-105-1 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Loving Pablo, Hating Escobar''''' is the translation of the title "''Amando a Pablo, odiando a Escobar''", a memoir of the Colombian author and journalist [[Virginia Vallejo]]. It was originally written in Spanish and was published by [[Random House|Random House Mondadori]] on 22 September 2007, and [[Random House|Random House Inc.]] of New York on 4 October 2007.{{cite web |url=https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/182336/loving-pablo-loving-pablo-hating-escobar-mti-by-virginia-vallejo/9780525433385/ |title=Loving Pablo, Hating Escobar. Random House. |access-date=2017-10-03}} The book describes the five years-long (1982-1987) romantic relationship of the author with [[Pablo Escobar]], head of the [[Medellin Cartel|Medellin cartel]], and it became instantly the #1 bestseller in [[Colombia]], [[Latin America]], and the Hispanic market in the [[United States]]. It has been translated to sixteen languages, and inspired the movie ''[[Loving Pablo]]'' (2017).{{cite web |url=http://www.lovingpablo.com/ |title=Loving Pablo, official website |access-date=2017-10-03}}{{cite news |last=Young |first=Deborah |date=5 September 2017 |title=Loving Pablo: Film Review. Venice 2017 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/loving-pablo-review-1035646 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |location= |access-date=3 October 2017}} Vallejo’s memoir is also her personal intimate biography of [[Pablo Escobar]]; a moving and terrible love story with many facets, but also a historical document about Colombian tragedies and political corruption in the second part of the 20th century.{{cite web |url=https://www.allenandunwin.com/browse/books/general-books/biography-autobiography/Loving-Pablo-Hating-Escobar-Virginia-Vallejo-translated-by-Megan-McDowell-9781786891051 |title=Biography and autobiographical book|access-date=2017-10-03}} ==Plot== The book is divided in an introduction and three parts: The Days of Innocence and Dreams; The Days of Splendor and Terror; and The Days of Absence and Silence. In the Introduction, Virginia Vallejo describes her departure from Colombia on 18 July 2006 in a special flight of the US [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] (DEA), after she has accused a former senator and minister of justice, [[Alberto Santofimio]], of instigating the assassination of a former presidential candidate, [[Luis Carlos Galan]], and after she had offered her cooperation to the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] in ongoing high-profile criminal cases.{{cite news |last=Goodman |first=Joshua |date=19 July 2006 |title=Pablo Escobar's Ex-Lover Flees Colombia |url=http://www.foxnews.com/wires/2006Jul18/0,4670,ColombiaEscobarapossLover,00.html |work=Fox News |location= |access-date=3 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Muse |first=To |date=1 October 2006 |title=Drug lord's lover enthralls Colombia socialite makes allegations against elite |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2006/10/01/drug-lords-lover-enthralls-colombia-span-classbankheadsocialite-makes-allegations-against-elite-span/052150f2-332b-4464-935e-a287670e72ba/ |work=The Washington Post |location=Bogotá |access-date=3 October 2017}} The story begins with the joy and passion of two new lovers -Pablo, an ambitious rookie politician from humble origins, and Virginia, a socialite and media personality, both 32 years old- and continues with the evolution of their relationship and Escobar’s personality during his war against the extradition treaty between Colombia and the United States, and the terrorist activities of him and the [[Medellin Cartel|Medellin cartel]] in their last years.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sptPGJv0a94&t=15s |title="Cómo conocí a Pablo Escobar" |date=30 September 2007 |access-date=3 October 2017 |language=Spanish |trans-title="How to met Pablo Escobar"}} Like a snowball, Vallejo describes the birth and boom of the cocaine industry that turned her lover into a billionaire, thanks to the cooperation of leading politicians; the origins of the Colombian rebel organizations, and the paramilitary squads founded by Escobar and his partners; the assassinations of the justice minister [[Rodrigo Lara Bonilla|Rodrigo Lara]] in 1984, and the [[Palace of Justice siege|siege of the Palace of Justice]] in 1985; the suffering of the journalist after she had ended her relationship with the drug kingpin in 1987, and her cooperation with the anti drug German agency [[Federal Criminal Police Office (Germany)|BKA]] in 1988; the Cuban connection, and the bombing of an airplane with 110 people on board in 1989 ([[Avianca Flight 203]]); the assassination of [[Luis Carlos Galán]], and three more presidential candidates; the origins of Escobar’s war against the [[Cali Cartel|Cali cartel]] and the Colombian state, followed by the era of [[Narcoterrorism|narcoterrorism]] from 1988 to 1993; the coalition of enforcement agencies and Escobar’s enemies involved in his hunt; and, finally, the worldwide reaction to the death of the Number One Enemy of the United States on 2 December 1993.{{cite web |url=http://www.randomhouse.com/highschool/catalog/display.pperl?isbn=9780525433385 |title=About the book: Loving Pablo |access-date=2017-10-03}} ==Reaction== The release of the book created a political scandal in Latin America and the Hispanic television channels in the USA, due to Vallejo’s description of the relationship of Pablo Escobar and the [[Medellín Cartel|Medellin]] and [[Cali Cartel|Cali cartels]] with several presidents - like [[Alvaro Uribe Velez|Alvaro Uribe]], [[Alfonso López Michelsen|Alfonso López]] and [[Ernesto Samper Pizano|Ernesto Samper]] - and Colombian enforcement agencies.{{cite news |author= |title=Colombian general jailed for 30 years over Galan death |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-38101907 |work=BBC |location= |date=25 November 2016 |access-date=4 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Romero |first=Simon |date=2 October 2007 |title=Colombian Leader Disputes Claim of Tie to Cocaine Kingpin |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/03/world/americas/03colombia.html?mcubz=1 |work=The New York Times |location=Bogotá |access-date=3 October 2017}} Thanks to Vallejo’s revelations, the Colombian government reopened the so-called "cases of the century": the [[Palace of Justice siege|siege of the Palace of Justice]], followed by a massacre of more than 100 people, including eleven Supreme Court Justices, committed by the army; and the assassination of [[Luis Carlos Galán|Luis Carlos Galan]] in 1989.{{cite news |date=18 August 2008 |title=Virginia Vallejo es nueva testigo en holocausto del palacio |trans-title=Virginia Vallejo is new witness in palace holocaust |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hyFzBpA3dXU |language=Spanish |work=Noticias Uno |location=Bogotá |access-date=3 October 2017}} Vallejo’s book was commented by [[The New York Times]] and [[El País]] of Madrid, among hundreds of media worldwide.{{cite news |last=Romero |first=Simon |date=3 October 2007 |title=President Uribe of Colombia denies ties to Escobar |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/03/world/americas/03iht-colombia.1.7730056.html |work=The New York Times |location=Bogotá |access-date=3 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Relea |first=Frances |date=4 October 2017 |title="El narcoestado soñado por Escobar tiene más vigencia que nunca" |trans-title="The narco-state dreamed by Escobar is more present than ever" |url=https://elpais.com/diario/2007/10/14/internacional/1192312810_850215.html |language=Spanish |work=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=3 October 2017}} Also, by Colombian, Venezuelan and Ecuadorian presidents, a former American ambassador to Bogota, human rights organizations, and the rebel [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia|FARC]].{{cite web |url=http://www.semana.com/politica/multimedia/hugo-chavez-dice-alvaro-uribe-peor-vito-corleone/140847-3 |title=Hugo Chávez llama a Uribe "Vito corleone" |date=9 November 2009 |access-date=3 October 2017 |language=Spanish |trans-title=President Hugo Chávez calls to Álvaro Uribe as "Vito Corleone" by book "Amando a Pablo, odiando a Escobar"}}{{cite news |last=Gómez |first=Jorge |date=18 April 2017 |title=Embajador Frechette habla sobre Uribe y la relación con el narcotráfico |trans-title=Frechette talks about Álvaro Uribe |url=http://colombia2020.elespectador.com/politica/los-militares-tienen-santos-bajo-chantaje-myles-frechette |language=Spanish |work=El Espectador |location=Bogotá |access-date=3 October 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2007/10/08/colombia-uribe-must-respect-judicial-independence |publisher=Human Rights Watch | title=Colombia: Uribe Must Respect Judicial Independence |date=8 October 2007 | access-date=7 July 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x1m9aei |title=FARC denuncia la trayectoria gangsteril de Álvaro Uribe |date=4 March 2014 |access-date=3 October 2017 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Farc denounces Álvaro Uribe's criminal record}} In 2008 and 2009, president [[Rafael Correa]] of [[Ecuador]] showed "''Amando a Pablo, odiando a Escobar''" on television.{{cite news |last= |first= |date=12 July 2009 |title=Correa desafía a abogados colombianos |trans-title=President Correa challenges Colombian lawyers |url=https://lahora.com.ec/noticia/903014/en-el-enlace-radial-128-el-presidente-de-ecuador-rafael-correa-retc3b3-a-los-abogados-colombianos-a-que-lleven-su-demanda-la-corte-penal-internacional-(cpi)-dijo-que-estc3a1-dispuesto-a-demostrar-que-los-terroristas-y-quienes-tienen-vc3adnculos-con-el-narcotrc3a1fico-no-son-de-ecuador-sino-del-gobierno-de-colombia-0d |language=Spanish |work=La Hora |location=Quito |access-date=3 October 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.amandoapablo.com/comentarios.html |title=President Correa show the book “Amando a Pablo, odiando a Escobar” |access-date=2017-10-03}} ==Political asylum to the author== On 3 June 2010, the United States of America granted political asylum to the Colombian author under the precepts of the [[United States Constitution|American Constitution]], the [[United Nations Convention against Torture|Geneva Convention Against Torture]], and the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]].{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2jJqBEMG84M |title=Virgnia Vallejo explica su asilo político (Minuto 1:20) |date=4 June 2014 |access-date=3 October 2017 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Virginia Vallejo explains her political asylum (minute 1:20)}} The decision of the judge was based on Virginia Vallejo’s career of decades as a journalist; her testimonies under oath in historic criminal cases that resulted in lengthy convictions; her description of atrocities and massacres in her book and in the court; the threats that she had received from members of the Colombian Government and the [[Right-wing paramilitarism in Colombia|paramilitary]]; and the brutal character assassination of the journalist in media owned by presidential families or their powerful associates, all of them documented in hundreds of pages of evidence and later erased from the Internet.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u0aNaavmcv4 |title=Political Asylum to Virginia Vallejo, CNN |date=6 November 2007 |access-date=3 October 2017 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Political Asylum to Virginia Vallejo, CNN}}{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Etgh1pGU7e0 |title=Los narcopresidentes colombianos |date=28 November 2008 |access-date=3 October 2017 |language=Spanish |trans-title=The Colombian narco-presidents}}{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hcav-WbM2Fg |title=Los enemigos de Virginia Vallejo |date=28 November 2008 |access-date=3 October 2017 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Virginia Vallejo’s enemies}} ==Translations== According to the author’s agent, Liepman AG of Zürich, the book "''Amando a Pablo, odiando a Escobar''" will be released in foreign languages during 2017. The countries and publishers are, in alphabetical order:{{cite web |url=http://www.thespanishbookstage.com/newsletters/loving-pablo-hating-escobar-virginia-vallejo-making-waves-overseas-2/ |title=The Spanish Bookstage: Translations of Loving Pablo, Hating Escobar |access-date=2017-10-03}}{{cite web |url=http://www.liepmanagency.com/de/authors/ |title=Authors of Liepman Agency |access-date=2017-10-03}} * [[Brazil]], Globo livros. * [[Czech Republic]], Euromedia Group. * [[Denmark]], Rosinante. * [[Egypt]], Al Arabi Publishing. * [[Finland]], Like Publishing. * [[France]], J’ai lu (of [[Groupe Flammarion|Flammarion]]). * [[Germany]], Lübbe. * [[Greece]], [[Psichogios Publications]]. * [[Hungary]], Partvonal (of Melotrade). * [[Italy]], Giunti Editore. * [[Poland]], Agora SA. * [[Portugal]], [[Penguin Random House|Penguin Random House Portugal]]. * [[Romania]], Grup Media Litera. * [[Russia]], [[Eksmo]]. * [[Slovakia]], Aktuell. * [[Spain]] and [[Latin America]], Peninsula (of [[Planeta Group|Planeta]]). * [[Turkey]], Mona Kitap. * [[United Kingdom]], [[Canongate Books|Canongate]]. * [[United States]], [[Vintage Books|Vintage]] and Vintage Español (of Knopf Doubleday/[[Penguin Random House]]). The Greek, Polish, Brazilian, Dutch and Finnish books were released in the first semester of 2017;{{cite web |url=http://globolivros.globo.com/livros/amando-pablo-odiando-escobar |title=Glovo libros publishing |access-date=2017-10-03}} the rest came out in late 2017 and early 2018. Planeta released "''Amando a Pablo, odiando a Escobar''" in Spain on 25 October 2017. The Latin American releases have not been confirmed yet. Vintage-[[Doubleday (publisher)|Knopf Doubleday]] launched both the Spanish and English titles in North America on 29 May 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.planetadelibros.com/libro-amando-a-pablo-odiando-a-escobar/254673 |title=Planeta publishing |access-date=2017-10-03}} ==The movie ''Loving Pablo'' (2017)== The film [[Loving Pablo]] is based on Vallejo’s book, and was released on 6 September 2017 during the [[74th Venice International Film Festival|74th Venice Film Festival]]. The role of the journalist is played by [[Penélope Cruz]], while the drug kingpin by [[Javier Bardem]], both winners of the Oscar of the [[Academy Awards|Academy of Hollywood]] as best supporting actors.{{cite news |last=Tartaglione |first=Nancy |date=30 August 2017 |title=‘Loving Pablo’ Clips, Javier Bardem & Penelope Cruz Take On Escobar – Venice |url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/loving-pablo-javier-bardem-penelope-cruz-video-venice-1202158317/ |work=Deadline |location=Hollywood |access-date=3 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Rankin |first=Seija |date=1 September 2017 |title=Javier Bardem on becoming Pablo Escobar for his new film, Loving Pablo—and reuniting with Penelope Cruz onscreen |url=http://www.eonline.com/news/877399/javier-bardem-on-becoming-pablo-escobar-for-his-new-film-loving-pablo-and-reuniting-with-penelope-cruz-onscreen |work= E News |location= |access-date=3 October 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.lovingpablo.com/ About the book] * [http://www.virginiavallejo.com/ About the author, Virginia Vallejo] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Loving Pablo, Hating Escobar}} [[Category:2007 non-fiction books]] [[Category:2017 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Memoirs]] [[Category:Biographies (books)]] [[Category:Random House books]] [[Category:Doubleday (publisher) books]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about Pablo Escobar]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about Colombian drug cartels]] [[Category:History books]] [[Category:Books about Colombia]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]]

'''Lucjan Dobroszycki''' (1925 – October 24, 1995 in [[New York City]]) was a [[Poland|Polish]] scientist and historian specializing in modern Polish and [[History of Jews in Poland|Polish-Jewish history]]. A survivor of the [[Łódź Ghetto]] and [[Nazi concentration camps]] including [[Auschwitz]], Dobroszycki lived in Poland after [[World War II]] where he obtained his education and worked as a historian. His main focus was the [[Occupation of Poland (1939–1945)|Nazi German occupation of Poland]]. Dobroszycki undertook studies of the – legal and illegal – Polish press from during [[World War II|the war]], edited an abridged version of the chronicle of the [[Łódź Ghetto]] (Litzmannstadt Ghetto), and conducted research on the extermination of Polish Jewry. He was a visiting scholar in [[Jerusalem]] in June 1967 and emigrated to the United States in 1970. He and his family settled in New York City where, for the remainder of his life he was a member of the research staff of the [[YIVO]] Institute for Jewish Research. He was also affiliated with [[Yeshiva University]]'s [[Holocaust]] studies program. According to Zachary Baker from Stanford, Dobroszycki became YIVO's "'research consultant to the stars'; he compiled a history of former New York mayor Ed Koch's ancestors and was a consultant to [[Barbra Streisand]]'s film production of "[[Yentl]]" (an indirect [[Yiddish]] connection). His name has appeared in numerous published acknowledgments and documentary film credits."[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:jXtD-m8C-f4J:www.ibiblio.net/pub/academic/languages/yiddish/mendele/vol5.151+Lucjan+Dobroszycki&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=3&gl=ca Lucjan Dobroszycki at www.ibiblio.net] [[File:Łódź, Litzmannstadt Ghetto - fotopolska.eu (295152).jpg|thumb|200px|Men haul a cart down the street in the ghetto]] ==''The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto''== One of Dobroszycki's crowning achievements as a historian was the publication of the collected accounts of Jewish life under the [[Nazi]] occupation of [[Łódź]], a day-by-day record of life in [[Łódź Ghetto|the second-largest Jewish ghetto in Nazi Europe]]. Only two of five projected volumes were published before Dr. Dobroszycki moved to New York in 1970. The first English translation of "The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto" was published by Yale University Press in 1984. In his review, Stefan Kanfer of Time.com reflected on the collected accounts:
"Within the barbed-wire boundaries a microcosm arose... Children were born, stores were opened, a road constructed, hospitals set up, administrators employed, records kept. It is these records, miraculously preserved in private libraries and underground caches, that provide the first detailed portrait of a Holocaust society. In ''The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto'', Editor Lucjan Dobroszycki, a survivor, presents an eerie and horrific scene told in terse entries, like a nightmare dreamed in pieces."[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,952526,00.html?promoid=googlep Stefan Kanfer, ''The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto'']
===Polish award=== Lucjan Dobroszycki was posthumously awarded ''[[Polityka]]'' magazine's Historical Award for the year 2006, on the 50th anniversary of its inauguration. ==Works== * ''Image Before My Eyes A Photographic History of Jewish Life in Poland 1864–1939'' with [[Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett]] (Hardcover, 1977) {{ISBN|0-8052-3607-4}} * ''Image Before My Eyes: A Photographic History of Jewish Life in Poland, 1864-1939'' with [[Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett]] (Paperback, Sep 13, 1987. Other Editions: Hardcover) {{ISBN|0-8052-0634-5}} * ''Image Before My Eyes: A Photographic History of Jewish Life in Poland Before the Holocaust'' with [[Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett]] (Paperback, Nov 1, 1994) {{ISBN|0-8052-1026-1}} * ''The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto, 1941-1944'' (Abridged edition, hardcover, 1984) {{ISBN|0-300-03208-0}}; (Paperback, 1987) {{ISBN|0-300-03924-7}} * ''The Jews in Polish Culture (Jewish Lives) by Aleksander Hertz, [[Czesław Miłosz]], Lucjan Dobroszycki, and Richard Lourie'' (Paperback, Aug 1, 1988. Other Editions: Hardcover) {{ISBN|0-8101-0758-9}} * ''Reptile Journalism: The Official Polish-Language Press under the Nazis, 1939-1945'' with Barbara Harshav (Hardcover, Dec 28, 1994) {{ISBN|0-300-05277-4}} * ''Hanukkah Lights: Stories from the Festival of Lights'' by Rebecca Goldstein, Harlan Ellison, Daniel Mark Epstein, and Lucjan Dobroszycki (Audio Cassette, Nov 9, 2001. Unabridged. Other Editions: Audio Cassette, Audio Download) {{ISBN|1-57453-459-9}} * ''The Chronicle of the Lodz Ghetto, 1941-1944'' (Paperback, 1984) * ''The Holocaust in the Soviet Union: Studies and Sources on the Destruction of the Jews in the Nazi-Occupied Territories of the USSR, 1941-1945'' with [[Jeffrey S. Gurock]] (Hardcover, Aug 1993. Other Editions: Paperback) {{ISBN|1-56324-173-0}} * ''Reptile Journalism: The Official Polish-Language Press under the Nazis'' (Hardcover, 1994) * ''Survivors of the Holocaust in Poland: A Portrait Based on Jewish Community Records 1944-1947'' (Hardcover, Nov 1994) {{ISBN|1-56324-463-2}} * ''Survivors of the Holocaust in Poland; A Portrait'' (Hardcover, 1994) * ''Ludność cywilna w Powstaniu Warszawskim'', vol. 3. in ''Prasa, druki ulotne i inne publikacje powstańcze''. Editors: [[Czesław Madajczyk]], Władysław Bartoszewski, Lucjan Dobroszycki, intro by W. Bartoszewski, Warszawa 1977. * ''Prasa, druki ulotne i inne publikacje powstancze'' by Czeslaw Madajczyk. {{Other people|Natalya Goncharova}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Natalia Sergeyevna Goncharova | image =Natalia Sergeyevna Goncharova.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Goncharova in 1910 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1881|7|3}} | birth_place = Nagaevo, [[Tula Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1962|10|17|1881|6|21}} | death_place = Paris, France | nationality = [[Russia]]n, [[France|French]] (since 1938) | field = Painting, [[costume design]], writer, [[illustrator]], [[set designer]] | training = [[Moscow School of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture|Moscow Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture]] | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }} '''Natalia Sergeevna Goncharova''' ({{lang-rus|Ната́лья Серге́евна Гончаро́ва|p=nɐˈtalʲjə sʲɪrˈɡʲejɪvnə ɡəntɕɐˈrovə}}; July 3, 1881 – October 17, 1962) was a [[Russia]]n [[avant-garde]] artist, [[Painting|painter]], [[costume designer]], writer, [[illustrator]], and [[set designer]]. She was a founding member of both the [[Jack of Diamonds (art)|Jack of Diamonds]], Moscow's first radical independent exhibiting group, and the art movement known as [[Der Blaue Reiter]]. Born in Russia, she moved to Paris in 1921 and lived there until her death.
==Early life == Natalia Sergeevna Goncharova was born on July 3, 1881, in Nagaevo (now in the [[Chernsky District]] of [[Tula Oblast]]).<ref name="Guggenheim Museum">{{cite book|title=Amazons of the avant-garde : Alexandra Exter, Natalia Goncharova, Liubov Popova, Olga Rozanova, Varvara Stepanova, and Nadezhda Udaltsova|first=|date=2000|publisher=Guggenheim Museum|year=|isbn=0-8109-6924-6|location=New York|page=155|pages=|chapter=Natalia Goncharova|quote=|author1=Sharp, Jane A.|editor1-last=Bowlt|editor1-first=John E.|editor2-last=Drutt|editor2-first=Matthew}}</ref> Her father, Sergey Mikhaylovich Goncharov, was an architect and graduate of the prestigious [[Moscow School of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture|Moscow Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture]].<ref name="Guggenheim Museum"/> Goncharova moved to [[Moscow]] at the age of 10 in 1892; she graduated from the Fourth Women's Gymnasium in 1898.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Sharp, Jane E.|editor1-last=Bowlt|editor1-first=John E.|editor2-last=Drutt|editor2-first=Matthew|title=Amazons of the avant-garde : Alexandra Exter, Natalia Goncharova, Liubov Popova, Olga Rozanova, Varvara Stepanova, and Nadezhda Udaltsova|date=2000|publisher=Guggenheim Museum|location=New York|isbn=0-8109-6924-6|page=156|chapter=Natalia Goncharova}}</ref>
== Education == In 1901 Goncharova began her own studies at the Moscow Institute of Painting, Sculpture and Architecture as a sculptor, under [[Paolo Troubetzkoy|Pavel Trubetskoi]], who was associated with the [[Mir iskusstva|World of Art]] movement.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gray|first1=Camilla|title=The Great Experiment: Russian Art 1863-1922|date=1962|publisher=Thames and Hudson|location=London|page=87}}</ref> By 1903, she began exhibiting in major Russian salons.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gray|first1=Camilla|title=The Great Experiment: Russian Art 1863-1922|date=1962|publisher=Thames and Hudson|location=London|page=88}}</ref> She was awarded a silver medal for sculpture in 1903-04.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book|title=Amazons of the avant-garde : Alexandra Exter, Natalia Goncharova, Liubov Popova, Olga Rozanova, Varvara Stepanova, and Nadezhda Udaltsova|first=|date=2000|publisher=Guggenheim Museum|year=|isbn=0-8109-6924-6|location=New York|page=158|pages=|chapter=Natalia Goncharova|quote=|author1=Sharp, Jane A.|editor1-last=Bowlt|editor1-first=John E.|editor2-last=Drutt|editor2-first=Matthew}}</ref> It was at the Moscow Institute that Goncharova met fellow-student [[Mikhail Larionov]], and not long afterwards they began sharing a studio and living space.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Наталия Гончарова. Между Востоком и Западом|url=http://www.museum.ru/N51091}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Михаил Ларионов и Наталия Гончарова|url=http://www.philol.msu.ru/~rki/advance-guard/larionov_goncharova.html}}</ref> She withdrew from the Moscow Institute in 1909, and in 1910, after a number of students were expelled from [[Konstantin Korovin]]'s portrait class for imitating the contemporary style of European Modernism, Goncharova, Larionov, [[Robert Falk]], [[Pyotr Konchalovsky]], [[Alexander V. Kuprin|Alexander Kuprin]], [[Ilya Mashkov]] and others formed Moscow's first radical independent exhibiting group, the [[Jack of Diamonds (artists)|Jack of Diamonds]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
== Participation in avant-garde movements == The Jack of Diamonds' first exhibition (December 1910-11) included [[Primitivism|Primitivist]] and [[Cubism|Cubist]] paintings by Goncharova, and in the later [[Donkey's Tail]] exhibition (March–April 1912) organized by Larionov, more than fifty of her paintings were on display.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Goncharova drew inspirations for primitivism from Russian icons and folk art, otherwise known as luboks.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://artinrussia.org/natalia-goncharova/|title=Natalia Goncharova - Art in Russia|website=artinrussia.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-11}}</ref> The Donkey's Tail was conceived as an intentional break from European art influence and the establishment of an independent Russian school of modern art. The exhibition proved controversial, and the censor confiscated Goncharova's religiously-themed work, ''The Evangelists'' (1910–11), deeming it [[blasphemy|blasphemous]] for it to be hung at an exhibition titled after the rear end of a donkey.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gray|first1=Camilla|title=The Great Experiment: Russian Art 1863-1922|date=1962|publisher=Thames and Hudson|location=London|page=87}}</ref> Goncharova and her counterpart, Larionov, were continuously harassed for their artwork and the way they expressed themselves.<ref name=":0" /> However, the influence of [[Russian Futurism]] is much in evidence in Goncharova's later paintings. Initially preoccupied with icon painting and the primitivism of ethnic Russian folk-art, Goncharova became famous in Russia for her Futurist work such as ''The Cyclist'' and her later [[Rayonism|Rayonist]] works. Goncharova and Larionav painted hieroglyphics and flowers on their faces and walked the streets as a part of a primitivist art movement. Goncharova herself sometimes appears topless in public with symbols on her chest.<ref name=":0" /> As leaders of the Moscow [[Futurism (art)|Futurist]]s, they organized provocative lecture evenings in the same vein as their Italian counterparts. Goncharova was also involved with graphic design—writing and illustrating several avant-garde books.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2002/russian/|title= The Russian Avant-Garde Book 1910 - 1934|publisher=[[Museum of Modern Art]] |access-date=2016-03-05}}</ref>
She started to exhibit at the [[Salon d'Automne]] (''Exposition de L'art Russe'') beginning in 1906.<ref>[http://www.salon-automne.com/2015/04/08/salon-dautomne-international-france-russie-a-saint-petersbourg-04-14-juin-2015-la-presentation-de-noel-coret/ Exposition de l'art russe 1906] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706081849/http://www.salon-automne.com/2015/04/08/salon-dautomne-international-france-russie-a-saint-petersbourg-04-14-juin-2015-la-presentation-de-noel-coret/ |date=2015-07-06 }}; salon-automne.com</ref>
Goncharova was a member of the avant-garde [[Der Blaue Reiter]] group from its founding in 1911. In 1915, she began to design ballet costumes and sets in [[Geneva]]. In 1915 she started work on a series of designs—''Six Winged Seraph'', ''Angel'', ''St. Andrew'', ''St. Mark'', ''Nativity'', and others—for a ballet commissioned by [[Sergei Diaghilev]] to be titled ''Liturgy''. Also involved in the project, for which [[Igor Stravinsky]] was invited to compose the score, were Larionov and [[Léonide Massine]], but the ballet never materialized.<ref>Norton, Leslie. ''Léonide Massine and the 20th Century Ballet'' . McFarland, 2004. p. 12. {{ISBN|0786417528}}</ref> Goncharova moved to Paris in 1921 where she designed a number of stage sets of Diaghilev's [[Ballets Russes]]. She also exhibited at the Salon d'Automne in 1921, and participated regularly at the [[Salon des Tuileries]] and the [[Salon des Indépendants]].
Goncharova and Larionav collaborated on four charity events in Moscow. These events were the Grand Bal des Aristes, the Bal Banal, the Bal Olympique, and the Grand Ourse Bal. They both designed much of the publicity materials for the event.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Federle|first=Courtney|date=1992-01-01|title=Kuchenmesser DADA: Hannah Höch's Cut Through the Field of Vision|jstor=20685953|journal=Qui Parle|volume=5|issue=2|pages=120–134}}</ref>
Between 1922 and 1926 Goncharova created fashion designs for [[Marie Cuttoli]]'s shop, Maison Myrbor on the Rue Vincent, Paris. Her richly embroidered and [[appliqué]]d dress designs were strongly influenced by Russian folk art, Byzantine mosaic and her work for the Ballets Russes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lussier|first=Suzanne|title=Art deco fashion|year=2006|publisher=V&A Publications|location=London|isbn=9781851773909|pages=46|edition=Repr.|quote=Goncharova's primitive interpretation of Russian folk art and Byzantine mosaics was evident not only in her costumes for the Ballets Russes but also in her designs for Myrbor}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Evening dress by Natalia Goncharova for Myrbor|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O72715/evening-dress-goncharova-natalia/|publisher=V&A Museum|accessdate=6 December 2012}}</ref>
In 1938 Goncharova became a French citizen.<ref name="Gugg">[http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/artists/bios/1257/Natalia%20Goncharova "Natalia Goncharova"], Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Retrieved 24 May 2015.</ref> On June 2, 1955, four years after Larionov suffered a stroke, the two artists got married in Paris to safeguard their rights of inheritance.<ref name=Gugg/> Goncharova died seven years later, on October 17, 1962, in Paris after a debilitating struggle with [[rheumatoid arthritis]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Amazons of the avant-garde : Alexandra Exter, Natalia Goncharova, Liubov Popova, Olga Rozanova, Varvara Stepanova, and Nadezhda Udaltsova|first=|date=2000|publisher=Guggenheim Museum|year=|isbn=0-8109-6924-6|location=New York|page=163|pages=|chapter=Natalia Goncharova|quote=|author1=Sharp, Jane A.|editor1-last=Bowlt|editor1-first=John E.|editor2-last=Drutt|editor2-first=Matthew}}</ref>
==Legacy== Goncharova's work can be found in a number of public institutions, including: *[[Museum of Modern Art]]<ref name="MoMA">{{Cite web |url=http://www.moma.org/collection/artist.php?artist_id=2229 |title=MoMA Collection: Natalia Goncharova |author=The Museum of Modern Art |authorlink=Museum of Modern Art |year=2010 |publisher=Moma.org |accessdate=25 November 2011 }}</ref> *[[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Goncharova, Natalia | work = Collections Online | publisher = Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa | date = | url = http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/party.aspx?irn=892 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 27 October 2011}}</ref> *[[Tate]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Natalya Goncharova | work = Tate Collection | publisher = the Tate | date = | url = http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ArtistWorks?cgroupid=999999961&artistid=1186 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 27 October 2011}}</ref> * [[Israel Museum]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Natalia Goncharova | work = The Israel Museum Exhibition Online | publisher = The Israel Museum | date = | url = http://www.imj.org.il/imagine/collections/item.asp?itemNum=192843 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 27 October 2011}}</ref> *[[McNay Art Museum]] <ref>{{cite web|author1=McNay Art Museum|title=McNay Collection: Natalia Gontcharova|url=http://collection.mcnayart.org/search.do?view=lightbox&collection=7&field-0=simpleSearchObject&bool-0=AND&keyword-0=gontcharova|publisher=Mcnayart.org|accessdate=16 May 2016|date=2014}}</ref> *Guggenheim, New York<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.guggenheim.org/artwork/1500|title=Cats (rayist percep.[tion] in rose, black, and yellow)|date=1913-01-01|work=Guggenheim|access-date=2017-03-11|language=en-US}}</ref> <gallery> File:Natalia Goncharova (self-portrait, 1907, GTG).jpg|''Self-portrait'' (1907) File:Babi s grablyami.jpg|''Women with rakes'' (1907) File:Khorovod.JPG|''Khorovod'' (1910) File:Cyclist (Goncharova, 1913).jpg|''Cyclist'' (1913) </gallery>
==Art market== [[File:Natalia Goncharova by M. Larionov (1915).jpg|thumb|right|''Portrait of Natalia Goncharova'' by [[Mikhail Larionov]] (1915)]] On June 18, 2007, Goncharova's 1909 painting ''Picking Apples'' was auctioned at [[Christie's]] for $9.8 million, setting a record for any female artist at the time.<ref>{{cite news | title=Who Was Natalia Goncharova? | url=http://www.nysun.com/article/57312 | publisher=[[The New York Sun]] | date=2007-06-26 | accessdate=2007-03-07}}</ref> She is considered one of the most expensive women artists at auction,<ref>{{cite news | title= artnet News's Top 10 Most Expensive Women Artists at Auction | url=https://news.artnet.com/market/most-expensive-women-artists-327329 | publisher=[[artnet]] | date=2015-08-31 | accessdate=2016-03-04}}</ref> and her work features in Russian art auctions during the bi-annual [[Russian Art Week]] in London.
In November 2007, ''Bluebells'', (1909), brought £3.1 million ($6.2 million).<ref>[http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/27606/artist-dossier-natalia-goncharova/ Artist Dossier: Natalia Goncharova]</ref> In 2008, Goncharova's 1912 still-life ''The Flowers'' (formerly part of [[Guillaume Apollinaire]]'s collection) sold for $10.8 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/market/most-expensive-women-artists-327329|title=The Most Expensive Women Artists - artnet News|date=2015-08-31|work=artnet News|access-date=2017-03-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=A Monet Sets a Record: $80.4 Million | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/25/arts/design/25auct.html?em&ex=1214625600&en=49db27f2e86469c1&ei=5087%0A | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=2008-06-25 | accessdate=2008-06-26 | first=Carol | last=Vogel}}</ref>
The copyright in the Estate of Natalia Goncharova is administered by ADAGP, Paris.
